I absolutely love this company and its motto. My only discord is that the pay is not efficient for the Office Assistant position.
This company absolutely meets all the standards they adhere to and I am happy to oblige because of the positive energy received.
Oh well, like I said, "I can certainly use a pay increase and not just 50 cents.
Incentive has severely diminished on the side of installation. some find going above and beyond unnecessary without recognition.

I answered the questions the way I did because yes I do believe the company is headed the right way, however there are things i believe could be fine tuned and adjusted to make things not only easier but more efficient in many ways. The ones I strongly agree on I love my job and am very good in warehouse work I was actually a manager in my last warehouse job that I had. There is a very good working atmosphere and while working and doing that safely I have a lot of fun working and coming to work and I have also encouraged my friends to apply for any position with Vivint.

Already introduced several friends/family to come work for Vivint Solar.

I feel like us who use desktop computers are getting bogged down--they are getting quite slow.  I find it difficult to work on multiple projects (Excel, Powerpoint, web browsers) at the same time without bogging down my computer, and needing to do daily (and sometimes more so) restarts during the day.
It doesn't totally feel like the company is moving any direction while we wait for this acquisition.

Some customer relations and scheduling roles should be relocated into their respective regions or offices for better communication and synergy.\\We need to do a better job of innovating with our processes, products and services, to deliver a product that cannot be offered by a competitor.\\Lobby congress for new rebates! If big oil can get them so should we!\\Thank You Greg

I feel before Vivint Solar was a corporation, it was very family-oriented and strongly molded together.  I started working for this company because of my older brother who only said amazing things.  When I first began working for the company, I loved it.  Lately, it's been such a different place.  My older brother ended up getting laid off a couple weeks ago, along with 9 other techs from our office.  It's definitely a lonely place to work now.  It almost feels like there's no more hope  or happiness in the office.  Vivint Solar has always treated me great, and I'm very appreciative of it, but since this merge that's supposed to happen, I feel like Vivint lost sight of their employees and "family first" motto.

Every single day I come to work I am surrounded by my Vivint family . The team we have in Pioneer Valley is unlike anything I've ever experienced . There is love , respect and motivation to help one another do better everyday .
Not totally sure about what is going on with this acquisition. It doesn't seem like its working out very well so far.

To my understanding one of the reasons we are doing the deal with SunEdison is because we are cash poor. I understand that it won't change everything but I think by not spending millions of dollars on incentives/gift cards/ Mediterranean cruises, we will not be as cash poor as we are now. The sales reps do deserve a lot of credit because they help keep our company moving forward, however, I think it is excessive.
The scheduling is a bit aggressive at times. This, coupled with the fact that direction on projects seem to change often, results in some disorganization at work.
Are we going to get an update on the SunEdison deal?
I strongly believe in the future of this company. as an assistant OM i have seen many improvements that will boost our efficiency and the public perception of us.

I believe that more resources would definitely assist in daily operations and that we are in a holding pattern due to finances related to merger. I also am working on cultivating and motivating the beneficial employees while weeding out the non-dedicated ones that act as a weight/negatively impact morale and productivity
I am excited about the future of this company/office. with larger resources, proper screening/training of employees, structure, standards and positive recognition, this office will be amazing!
Vivint is a great company because of the people that work here and how team oriented the company is as well.
There are a few things I think that shouldn't of changed in the company as it makes things more difficult then it did before.

There are times that sometimes we need to work past out time to make sure we can get out job done and done smoothly but that has been changed and are now are not able to and have to put some work on hold that requires immediate attention because we need to make sure we are out at our 8 hrs and we were told that we would get e-mails to let us know of changes and issues with accounts and that has not happened.

There are certain things that we changed and added for the company to do and I do not think that if works for all markets or offices as certain markets require different things and may not require the new changes that are taking place and because of these new changes it is causing a huge backlog for our work to move forward and to be done correctly. The whole AB2FIN process is broken and is not functioning I don't think they way it should be as there are times that things to not make it to the proper buckets due to different departments have a huge back log which then makes a trickle effect and makes all other departments to have a backlog. I would like to see the company master all of the processes but they need to be functioning properly before we can have a positive outcome and I also believe that people who are deserving of it should be recognized for there hard work. I also believe that the office people do not get included in certain incentives that are run and that is not fair because office people work just as hard as the OPS crews and the Sales Managers and it would be nice to see incentives go out to the office crews as well such as the LIT's and the OA's.

I love the opportunity I have here.  I'm excited for the future but I'm concerned with the general direction of the company at times. Some of this is tied to the pending transaction and some of it is tied to the number of individuals I've spoken with recently who have expressed their uneasiness and concern with their roles.  I see our dedication to Ops and Sales and I'm thankful for that, but I also see a lot of corporate employees that look at this like a job vs. career and I think that has a lot to do with a lack of clear career paths and overall interest from the company in the G&A positions vs. the Sales/Ops attention. Don't get me wrong, I know that Sales drives our business and I know that Ops closes out the work that Sales generates. In fact, I'm moving from being the HR Director over Sales to become a Sales Manager. But I know that in order for our company to truly thrive, we need an entire group of individuals (the entire company from top to bottom) bought into the culture, mission, values and excitement that many of our field folks have.  I'd love to see a more thoughtful approach to career paths, culture and recognition for our people and groups not in the field. Personally, the decision to leave HR and go to Sales was difficult.  I love interfacing with and helping Chance and his group.  I know the impact I've had in their area but at the same time, I feel like I can have a stronger overall impact on the company, culture, values and ultimately goals (MW Installed and Cost Per Watt savings) by going out into the Sales world and bringing my unique perspective and abilities to the field and eventually to Sales Leadership.  I hope that makes sense.
The answers above are strictly related to my current role as HR Director for Sales.

I'm truly excited for the future of this company.  I know we are going through some difficult times but I also know that we have the right people at corporate to climb this mountain and see the vista at the top.  It will just take some patience and time (I'm willing to give both).  We just need to make sure we recognize them and let them know how important they are.  Otherwise, we stand to lose more than we already have.

I have enjoyed working for Vivint Solar since my first day. The location I work in is full of dedicated individuals who work together for the good of the company. I understand the company is going through changes but I will do whatever it takes to help towards the companies goals. My only issue is that I feel like my department is overshadowed by other departments and we do not get the appreciation like other departments.

I just want to say that Vivint Solar is my home! I love coming to work. I've made many sacrifices for the company missing family time (working Sunday's & Holidays) but I am not complaining. I am here to do whatever I can for the company.

To start I want to say that I am very grateful for the opportunities I have had with this company and feel very blessed. The reason I shared my answers the way I did is because this is a very sales based company. Understandably so, but because of this I feel that we are forgetting our purpose and what we are trying to accomplish. I would be worried to give a sales reps info to someone I have spoken with because I am worried they will be mislead or not taken care of. Very few do I feel that I can refer. I understand this is case by case and depends on the sales rep. I just want to feel confident when I hand them a card or give their information to know they will be taken care of. And that we dont just see people as a paycheck. I know we are a business and we want to make money, but I feel like the employees and customers get forgotten along the way. I appreciate you wanting to hear from us, and again, I am very grateful for the opportunities this company has given me. I hope that this helps!

Part of the reason the answers are the way they are is because I am in a brand new office in a brand new state. There has been a lot of ups and downs trying to figure things out. It takes awhile to get everything set up so that I can be as efficient as possible. Also being in a new position (from permit specialist to OA) every office seems to have their own way of doing things, so I am just trying to find my nitch and what is expected of me.

I like where we're going with some of the recent developments, such as offering the new loan product, expanding into new states, etc. However, the pending SunEdison acquisition has provided a lot of uncertainty. It has been going on for several months, and it still remains unclear what the future holds for me and others in the Company. Additionally, we all see SunEdison getting beat up in the market, and that provides additional worry since who knows if this company acquiring us is even going to be around long-term.

We do get a fair amount of communication about developments in the Company, but not always on the quarterly or annual goals and progress toward those goals. While I feel my supervisors are good at keeping me informed, I don't think they always give me the background I need to do certain assignments. Also, I feel like some assignments I get are just unpleasant tasks they don't want to do. Additionally, while many people are committed to work, I have had instances where I'm trying to track down information and people don't take ownership for their areas and just pass the buck on to someone else.

Bonuses have been on our minds lately, as we're approaching the end of the year. I don't think we've had the progress on bonuses communicated to us very well. We don't really know where the Company is on those goals, or if we can expect a bonus. Additionally, non-sales personnel kind of feel that bonuses are beyond our control, our bonuses are hostage to how well the sales people perform, which is somewhat discouraging. Transitioning to Google from Office programs has been difficult too, many of us don't feel we have the same kind of functionality. We also really don't want to lose the P drive.
The reason why I like Vivint so much is the opportunities for growth. There are many aspects of the company left to learn and I know that Vivint and fellow employees are willing to teach me.
If I could add anything it would be a link through our learning center to apply for other positions within the company so I can see what positions are available to apply for

If the purpose of the company is to recreate the energy grid in this country into something more sustainable and something that mimics nature then we are on the right track.  If the purpose of the company is to make money for investors and other stakeholders than I'm not sure the company is moving in the right direction.  Also, as a side note measuring our costs against costs of traditional centralized power generation systems may not indicate whether we are doing a good to the earth.  Instead we might just be doing something not as bad.  Because centralized power generation is less efficient than distributed power generation it doesn't mean our current method of distributed power generation is the answer to all that ails the world in the domain of power consumption. It may still be a step in the wrong direction, just a smaller step.

As a company we have clearly been distracted by the pending purchase by SunEdison.  This distraction and the related noise that comes with it makes being "informed" difficult to define.  It also makes hearing what the executive team wants to say difficult to hear.

It is okay for a "for-profit" organization to be in the business of making money.  There is no shame in making money.  The more we try to sell ourselves as a company that is changing the world the lower my confidence is that the company can actually make money.  Religions and Dictators sell ideals and values.  If you're not a religion or dictatorship and you're trying to sell me values it makes me think I don't need what you're selling, what you're selling isn't worth its price, or you don't believe the product you sell has any value.  I want to read publicly that Vivint Solar is a good place to make money and it may be a more efficient way to power your home than buying power from the utility.

I feel very like I am accomplishing alot for both vivint and myself but would not mind doing more. I've been installing for almost 2 half years now. I am now foreman , but I wouldn't mind to be a little more invovled in Vivint. ( run an office or what not) I came to big island to work and I now have a girlfriend here with 3 kids and I would like to have a more stable foundation to bring both my family and vivint success. \\- Corbin T. Brueche

I am working in a vba position and it seems that no one wants/will use anything we produce without significant prodding from higher management. This seems contradictory as the people who request our services are usually the ones who are least likely to use what we make.

I feel that there is an issue with the CSM team in general. As I pull statistics and monitor most of what they do it is really disheartening to see how poorly they are doing. This makes it hard to stay motivated as I make less than them and do everything to make their job literally automated. I don't mean to be harsh but it really is causing a serious morale problem for my team.

As an office administrator I often feel left out.  We are not told about the goals we should be working toward and are not given incentives that we have control of very often.  While I worked at corporate I felt very included.  I felt as if my opinion mattered and made a difference.  I now see the lack of communication in the field and why people are not very motivated.  The focus is so much on sales and rarely on operations.

When I was hired I was never really told what I was supposed to be doing.  I was shown how to submit permits (which I was just told isn't my job) and then I had to figure the rest out on my own. There are days that I never even see my manager.  Almost everyday he walks into the office says Hi and then I don't hear from him for the rest of the day.  I have not ever received feedback of whether I am doing a good job or I am not doing a good job.

I am really passionate about what we do here at Vivint Solar. I love working for this company and I am really scared of how that is diminishing. It is really important for people to know what exactly they are supposed to do and what their responsibilities are and then they need to be praised or reprimanded for the work they are doing.

I feel like this is a great company to work for, since it helps people save money on their energy. I'm not passionate in the movement but I like being on a computer and listening to music and conversing with friends.

There is book called, "Drive" that talks about motivation. Of all of the leadership books I've read, I feel that the best way to accomplish the greatest improvement in the company is to apply the principles found in the book "Drive."

This is a great company to work for and the opportunities are amazing. Back end support is not always the greatest and it seems that coporate ( processing mainly) takes extensive time to resolve holds and to process paperwork. It is frustrating that documents have to be sent multiple times before they are even looked at. Overall I am loving working here and excited for the future

Vivint Solar is a great company. Although, the atmosphere is great in several ways, the communication is not so great and quite frankly some of the management isn't either. I feel that we as a company hurt ourselves with not following through or being too lenient on some. Not demoting someone because they are in a leadership position, from my experience has hurt teams and asks them to ignore an everyday issue. Which for anyone would be insulting. Vivint Solar has a lot of great things, as well! My personal team lead is amazing and does the best she possible can. Vivint Solar does a lot of things in regards to benefits that I am very grateful to have. I know a lot of people are nervous about the whole Sun Edison thing and have been in the dark for a long time. Hopefully we will get some clarity on that soon. Thank you for asking!
I really appreciate that you would even have us take a survey to see where things are at. Thank you!!
I love working for Vivint Solar and I love everything that we stand for.

I think it is important about the way we are moving forward and moving away from security on our own. I have referred my mom and brother in law to work here whom have both been hired. My mom was unfortunately not able to start as some unexpected medical conditions happened.
I feel like it would be more effective and resourceful if we had our second screens back as we do so much work that one screen makes it difficult.

The only thing I would suggest is that there be better communication and opportunities to move up from an internal position vs continuous hiring from outside the company. Other than that, everything is great!
Though the department I currently work in is very efficient and capable of getting work done, I feel like the other departments that we interact with aren't. I wish that could change.
Receiving support from other departments is usually a challenge. There is still a very strong feeling of corporate vs the field

Like most companies, there are major cliques that effect the way this company runs. I think if you are a male that does cross fit with the higher ups, you have a straight pathway to wherever you want to go. I know this is being addressed, but involving women more into our culture would change the moral of most of the women in the company.
Why the top guy in the last quarter in our office don't receive rewards..??
The merger holding everything up from moving forward is really difficult

I have always loved the culture and pride we have at Vivint.  I have always felt their is opportunity for growth in ownership that is always available, creating an environment of success and empowerment over our future.  Thank you for all that you do
I fell the information received, such as the new PPA, could be executed better.  I think that some processes could be more stream lined such as ESC.
The sales department is run very well! However customer service and operations is run very pooorly and is costing VIvint in reputation and future sales

The customer experience is probably the most important aspect of what we all do at Vivint Solar.\Going forward I am very concerned about customer service, installations and all aspects of field operations.Gregg I am available anytime to provide additional feedback. Please feel free to call me at 508-272-2060?\\Steve

I feel I don't really know what direction Vivint Solar is moving towards. Some days we're making progress only to fall back the next. Also, communication is key. Being part of the Customer Experience side (CSM), I feel that is just as important to all of us who work here.
I like working for the company and I believe in what the company offers to it's customers

I wish there was more communicated about the merger, what plan B is if it doesn't happen, whether I will still have a job. It is difficult planning my life, ie. buying a house, when rumors are if the merger does not happen a lot of cost cutting or jobs. I also wish there was more communication on how we are planning on growing, business development, commercial, community solar and why some of those things have not progressed. I also wish I was more involved in the strategic direction of the company.\\Thanks
As a CSM the workload has been increasing, taking on additional responsibilities without the proper training on the proper steps, policies, and protocol that needs to take place.

I love my job and love coming to work. admittedly there are days were i don't want to come to work but in the end I am pleased with my experience thus far here. the only downside in my view is the way that the company is going. What's going on with Sun Edison? How does it affect us? i don't think we are heading in the wrong direction I just wish I knew more about were the "ship is sailing" and if we are "on course" or off.
This is my company and my chosen career path. I just want to feel included even if i don't decide anything. Knowing something is better than knowing nothing at all.
I love working here at Vivint Solar because it is the first time I feel like I matter here and that I really believe in what we do here has a meaning and that we are helping others.
My team is more like my family we are always in the loop with what's going on and we help each other out which is great!

I love my job and what we do here! It is a great experience. I know there are changes and a lot to work on but that means we are progressing and that is awesome! Hope to meet you one day! Take care and thank you for taking the time to ask for my opinion!

I don't feel a part of the company because our management rarely communicates with me or my department. In the 7 months I have worked in the department I think my manager has maybe said 2 words to me. I don't think the executives above our department think of us as valuable or in-expendable.  I have rarely been given incentive to work hard or be better other than "job-security". I don't think that open positions are filled fairly. I think a lot of hiring decisions have been based off favoritism and not necessary skill or ability or even experience. Management is weak overall. I don't have doubts in upper management's skills or ability but I don't think we are being managed effectively on a personal standpoint. I don't know my manager, and I am confident he doesn't know me. To give him the benefit of the doubt, he may know me, but he has made no effort to demonstrate that.  This company can certainly benefit from more transparency. \My last grievance is that a lot of attention and money is going towards the sales side of the company. I am more than aware that they bring in the revenue and that is especially important in this industry, but I am also aware that it costs a whole lot less to keep a customer than it does to find a new one.
I don't think my department has an outlined strategy. We have goals and expectations but there is no overall strategy which is key.
Please refer back to my previous comments.

I neither agree nor disagree that the company is moving in the right direction because I am uneducated about this. I would agree because I feel that we are expanding at a great rate but would disagree because the companies publicity hasn't been stellar (from what I have come across). I am also nervous about the merger. I think this is hurting our potential as a company.

I know what is expected of me except that I am not well informed AT ALL. I have been in my position for about 2 months now and have not once received instruction. I am literally 100% self taught as a CAD supervisor. I am ok with this (because I work well by myself) but I do think that it is ridiculous for me to be expected to be accurate. Maybe it is my manager's strategy because they know my strengths but I disagree with it. I am never held accountable for my work, only threatened to be written up which I think is also rediculous. Everyone in the CAD department is hired off the street and nobody knows how to actually manage anyone. I receive emails from upper management and struggle to read through them because most of them don't apply to me. Because of that tendency, I do not give attention to your emails regularly.
I love working here. It has given me the chance to learn so much but operations in this company are very immature.

Ok so here are my concerns.. When there are problems there seems to be a email vortex that the messages go to. \Ma interconnection doesn't respond in a timely matter or sometimes at all. \Fleet performance is letting my customers down. I have many accounts not working and despite my efforts they are NOT  getting addressed.  \Things are not updated in Mercury so that I can affectively see when inspections are done. \I really appreciate my CSM staff
Room for improvement in electrical upgrade process

I feel the idea of saving people money on energy costs is something worth supporting. I also believe we are honest to the customer and accomplish things in an honorable way. I also enjoy working in the design department, i enjoy working with my team and would recommend anyone to join the vivint.solar team.

I've seldom had information disseminated to me in regard to company quarterly goals. Those goals are mostly kept to the supervisors and when we are behind, i feel they push for too much too late, rather than meet the quota from day 1.  My direct supervisor, Katherine Cornwall keeps our team as informed as she can, and is a great example of a leader. I enjoy working on Katherine's team.

While there are many thing I enjoy about working here, I feel there is little opportunity to grow career wise. I have been given responsibility beyond what my position calls for, and have happily accepted to help and do more whenever asked of me. I enjoy growth and have learned much from going outside my comfort zone. However, after doing such for so long, and not being given the opportunity of promotion, it chokes my willingness to go above and beyond. I feel as though there is a glass ceiling I am unable to break through.
I think it has been great! The only thing that could make it better would be having a company wide Christmas party like Vivint Inc does.
I think it has been great! The only thing that could make it better would be having a company wide Christmas party like Vivint Inc does.
This company is great!  The only thing that could make it better would be having a company wide Christmas party like Vivint Inc does.

I feel like my position is seen by others as unimportant and that it is looked over by almost all other departments, yet I feel like i handle some of the most demanding and complicated problems with out customers.

The expectations in my department have been changing on a regular basis. I am made aware sometimes of what is expected of me but sometimes I feel like i am kept in the dark and that things are happening and changing and I am not made aware of the changes or what the new expectations are until a few weeks later.
Changing the world has its prerequisite's.
I believe Vivint as a whole is moving in a positive direction.
At this point, it's pretty clear to me why I'm here. That's to have fun with what I do and get better every day. The environment at Vivint has been totally supportive.

Q1. In regards to the first question its hard for me to answer that question thoroughly, reason being is we aren't kept in the loop of whats going on. We get bits and peaces of whats going on or what may happen. So I feel the question cannot be answered with the options given.\\Q6. I feel I am a large part of the section of the company I work in, but out side my cubicle is  a completely different world out there Im not familiar with in any way. I have never been shown how the panels are put up, except for on pictures witch is no fun! or the different it makes once the system is up and running and the benefits it provides. These are just a few of the things that I would like to know more about so Im able to feel I know what this company does from beginning to end.

Q7: My direct Supervisor keeps us informed on what we need to do in our are of the company but other than our area, we dont hear much of whats going on.\\Q8: As soon as my Supervisor receives information she lets us know what is currently going on, but most the time I dont feel she has been told exactly what is going on.
There is so much on my mind I wouldn't be able to write it all down.

Working at Vivint, or Go, solar has been amazing so far. The office atmosphere could not be any better, and our leaders are ALWAYS willing to help. Leaving my last job was a blessing as I never would have known about the career you can have with Vivint. I am proud when I tell friends and family where I work because my job literally changes the world.

The only reason I did not put "strongly agree" is because of the many changes that are happening within the company at this stage. Sometimes Apollo crashes, but we have figured out ways around these issues. Also, the information regarding where out company is headed is sometimes confusing, but our leaders have been completely transparent with the information they receive.
I love working with this company. It has changed my life financially, and it is a blessing to know that our job is changing the world we live in in a positive way.
I am confident in the leaders we have in the company and feel we will adapt and overcome any challenges. I am looking forward to my future with Vivint Solar.
Leadership is not always transparent on what is going on in the company.

I feel communication can be difficult sometimes to help us resolve holds. For example, I've received multiple structural review holds and it would be much easier to be able to speak with the structural group personally to know what exactly would need to be done rather than try to communicate over email which can take days to get an answer.

There are a few management and expectation problems in specifically the operations side of the company and because of those issues I don't feel comfortable referring friends and family to work here.  From both what I have seen and heard, quite a few of the managers and supervisors in operations have negatively affected employee satisfaction and I would hate to put a referral of mine in an unhappy position.

I feel like I usually have to use my own resources to do my job succesfully.  At times it feels like Vivintsolar requires a lot from me but doesn't assist or compensate me equally to the requirements of my job. I also feel like most of the people I work with are content doing sub par work because the atmosphere is too lax and they see their superiors slacking off as well.

One thing that concerns me about the culture here at vivintsolar is the mentality of each man or team for themselves.  At least in operations, there seems to be problems between departments.  Each department thinks they are the most important and they forget that to accomplish our company mission and vision we have to work together.  People tend to see our company through their department and what makes their jobs easier instead of what is best for the company.\\Also the lack of communication and accountability causes so many problems in this company in all departments. \\Sometimes I feel like we cut corners especially when rolling out new processes and tools.  I also feel like pushing for numbers is going to get you poor CADs, poor installs, incorrectly processed documents etc.  \\I am also concerned about the lack of training for leadership.  I have seen quite a few situations that were completely against HR policies happen between operations leadership and their teams.  We have a young workforce, with very limited experience and we haven't trained them to manage teams, issues, and often times most of them don't even know how to do the job their teams do.  That can cause a lot of frustration for the team members.  I personally don't deal with that anymore because of my position but because of my position I am aware of these experiences and frustrations.\\Another concern I have is the mentality that we promote people out of work.  I feel like this "Mindset" could correlate to the problems we are experiencing with employee moral, efficiency and other problems.  When leaders appear to not be working it makes it easier for team members to feel like they don't have to work. \\I love working for VivintSolar.  I can honestly say my experience has for the most part been positive.  But I know of so many who have not had that experience and I honestly believe that if I had stayed in operations I would have left the company a long time ago.  I feel like the departments in Lehi are headed in the right direction, but operations is struggling.  My biggest concern for this company is the influence leaders have on their teams.  Great leaders can impact teams to do amazing things but poor leaders hold the whole company back and I am of the opinion that a lot of the leaders (who directly work with teams: team leads, supervisors and managers) in operations are holding the company back.
My current department feels disconnected from the rest of the company.
I feel like some departments here are Vivintsolar do not work effectively or are as committed as other departments.

There are certain departments that either need more efficient processes deployed, training, or employees.  Some of these departments include: work orders, and CAD.  We waste a lot of time in these sections of the solar process.
I love what I do at Vivint. I have worked is sales for over 15 years and by far Vivint is where I am supposed to be! I'm saving people money and helping the environment at the same time.
I love what I do at Vivint. I have worked is sales for over 15 years and by far Vivint is where I am supposed to be! I'm saving people money and helping the environment at the same time.

While direction is more important than speed, we need more speed. Not speed in getting more installs. Speed in the process post install. Lets clean up old accounts, then move forward. We will only improve our install numbers when we create happy customers who have gone quickly thru the process and then refer their friends and family! I think this is the most important focus we could have now.

I am not aware of our quarterly goals. I feel that there are too many processes, programs, etc that keep me from being efficient, i.e. 8 google docs I access daily for the info I need. My supervisor is excellent, but has too big of a workload to always communicate effectively.

I would love to see parallel processes  across the company. I moved from a West Coast team to an East Coast team this week, and while I understand local offices will always have different procedures, each office should schedule every job the same way. Visibility on inspections, scheduling thru Click, etc., needs to be the same. AB2FIN should be implemented by every team. \\CSM teams should have clearly set goals and incentives, however small, when goals are reached. There should be a clear career progression for CSMs so employees stay with us because they believe they can for years. \\We should also implement service to the community. Having been a beneficiary of Vivint Inc's Vivint Gives Back for my autistic son, they are changing lives for so many. I feel it helps employees feel like they really belong to a company when they can DO GOOD together.  Thanks, Greg!

I don't feel that everyone around me is committed to doing good work. I think it is easy to slack off when a job you are given is boring or tedious resulting is lower efficiency. Also, I think we should do more podcasts or short videos telling us where the company sits rather than emails. I don't read them because they are usually long. I would much rather watch a short video to stay informed.

I am personally more loyal and committed to a company that knows me and who I know more in personal terms. Can we have more interactions with our directors and executives? We don't get much face time with the people who lead or organizations and company and I think it would greatly increase loyalty and employee experience.

I am of the opinion that our internal customer experience organization needs a bit of work. I'm aware that we are still working out the kinks with the new structure, and new goals are being recognized and set in motion for 2016, but I see certain strategies being employed in many areas of the organization that seem counter-intuitive given the momentum at which our company is currently moving.

My particular role has clearly defined parameters, however, other roles do not. I've spoken with agents that find their roles to be ambiguous, or they think their responsibilities overlap those of other employees. Because of this, there are times when I cannot effectively do my job. The individual roles within our structure as a whole are designed to operate collectively.  To compare this to clockwork would suppose that working gears can become useless among too many broken cogs.

I sense a grave lack of urgency at the corporate level in terms of moving accounts through the various buckets. E.g., getting things submitted for utility approvals, scheduling inspections after install, etc. Recently certain steps in the process got put in the hands of the account managers but I feel that they are either over burdened with accounts or have a casual attitude toward them. there needs to be more clarity as to who is responsible for what in getting accounts to PTO. If I as the sales manager am responsible for getting accounts to PTO I am more than happy to do everything necessary but please give me the tools to do so. I shouldn't have to rely and wait on some single person who I may or may not be able to get a hold of, and who may or may not get back to me, or may or may not care very much. Either give me the ball or make sure the ones who have it want it. from where I am, it feels like unless I ride people's backs to get things done, they never would. I would rather do them myself. Another example: I had an account installed. Nothing seemed to be happening with its progression in a reasonable time so I emailed my account manager asking about it- he said it looks like it needs field work for the ab cad to be completed. He said he would email cad to find out what was needed to be done. Why did this have to wait for my inquiry to be taken care of or even noticed? What if I never asked? Would this have never been done? It's little things like this that have me concerned.
I think Vivint has done a good job moving forward. The only thing I'd wish for would be more marketing material that we could use during sales, explains our process and info to leave with customers.

I work part time so sometimes I don't feel involved as an employee, but I still love coming to work and if I have questions my supervisor helps me. I honestly don't exactly know what we are trying to accomplish as vivint solar, but I know Vivint Solar is a good company so I am proud to work here.

I work part time and our team meetings are on Tuesdays when I'm not here.  So I miss a lot of the new information that comes in.  I do not get a agenda or anything from the meeting, so I just learn as situations come up in the queue. My supervisor is not that great at informing me, but is it my responsibility to ask?  I'm not sure. And I don't know what we are needing to do this quarter in order to succeed.

This is a good company. Unfortunately I have to leave the company because I am not able to work 24 hours a week... I would loooove to keep working here! It's such a wonderful company and they really help make people feel special and needed here! In some cases, they make us feel a little too needed.  They work people overtime with special projects with short deadlines and I don't think that is fair for those employees.  The employees in that department are very dedicated and get the work done, but it's just hard on them because they all have to work 70+ hours a week. Other than that the company is good.  Of course there are ups and downs, they come with any company.  But Vivint Solar is one of the best companies around. The good outweighs the bad.

To answer that fully, I need to back pedal a little bit. Growing up, I knew I wanted to be involved in the technology industry. As a young adult, I had the good fortune of coming into the alarm business early. I quickly discovered that hard work and dedication pays off well there and grew with it for seven years, supporting me through school.\\When the time came that I wanted to lay some roots and continue to climb, I turned my ship towards solar which I had been following for awhile and had been exploding. It would be an easy transition with my skill set and followed with my long term goals. \\This may sound silly, but as a scuba diver, outdoorsmen, and gardener, I have a great concern for how we handle ourselves and the impact of our role on this planet. And while we are a business, we are playing a positive part in all that that I am stoked to be a part of. \\All that having been said, I have a lot of personal investment in where we are headed as a company. I have been impressed with both our success in redefining the home solar business and creating the opportunity for so many families to be a part of something they wouldn't otherwise have the means to do so.\\The biggest things I have had on my mind lately are first, are we doing everything that we can be both locally (especially here in Utah) and nationally to raise awareness and educate both individuals AND legislatures about the benefits of solar. And second, where is our process at integrating new technologies such as the home battery.\\As far as myself, my only pressing desire would be to be involved with everything in a bigger way, on more than individual accounts.
This front is well covered. I appreciate the different newsletters and things that we receive, particularly those of us in the field, that keep us informed.
I'm excited to see what 2016 has in store. The future is what we make it.

Because it's true.  I have worked in several leading companies, entry level through executive level.  Never have I worked with a team of incredibly talented driven people who are humble and success driven...not only success, but want to help me succeed personally.  It's a remarkable culture.

You shouldn't do anything if it can't be measured.  There are so many variables, systems and reports that help me do my job and measure how successful I am at doing it.  I am unable to do my job effectively because of things out of my control and because things that are out of Vivint's control.

It's a really exciting time in the industry and everybody is trying to move at warp speed...controlled chaos. I love it. \My big worry is about the brand. Online reviews aren't great.  A large percentage of my customers systems are not working. If there was any team of people that I know will get it fixed it's the people in this company...many of whom are what I consider to be foxhole friends.  I love being part of the revolution.  \Also, I stand by my survey submission and don't care about being anonymous.  Thanks for all that you do Greg. \Very gratefully  yours,\Jeff Evans\Badge 94928

I love Vivint Solar and what we do! I just wish things were a little more organized and we had more competent people working in our local office and at corporate. It seems like our turnover rate is high in the CAD department and everytime things seem to finally go smoothly with CAD, we have new CAD people and we're back to square one.
I feel like we could all be on the same page better. My managers, all though great, don't always seem to keep us informed with everything going on. I like to be informed and want to know everything.

Are we doing the merger with sun Edison and if so when? Also in San Diego Vivint solar was on the news. Kusi station and they published a bad story about a customer taking 15 months to get PTO'd and she still isn't PTO'd. Has that customer been helped? Were you aware of Vivint Solar being on the news? We need a PR person who helps with our branding and making sure we have all positive stuff on the news and online. \Also customers keep begging me for more panels. Can we please do add on accounts with only 8 panels rather than 12? I have like 10 installs I could get if we did 8 panels instead of 12 for add on accounts. And also sun run and solar city will go over 100% offset, I'm losing a lot of deals to them simply because customers want 110% oddest or 125% because they were so conservative with their usage and they don't want to have to wait to do an add on account.

I am extremely proud to work for this company and to be a part of the Vivint Solar family but I feel lately that I don't really know where we are going. I can speak for a lot of people around me when I say we feel like we are completely in the dark with the future of this company. We do less fun things and there is much less of an emphasis on doing things as a team. I understand why, with the merger and us growing to the size that we are, but I feel like when I started with this company 3 years ago it was exciting to come to work and it felt almost like a club more than a job. There is no positive reinforcement anymore and the expectations are all based on production numbers more than what you actually do for the team and company and people involved with us.

Although I am a big fan of solar energy and think that what we are doing is good, I am very frustrated with the work environment here. We are constantly being pushed to do much more work than we can physically do, and there is very little trust in our designers (my area) to do their job. I just feel like we are treated like machines that have to output X goal consistently or we're not doing our job, which is totally false. I look around at my team and see everyone working hard every day to do a good job, yet we are never able to meet our goals and higher-ups are constantly angry with us or having us work overtime to do the work of multiple people. The truth is, we have more work to do than we have people to do, and we can't be expected to just make up for that. Everyone I know here is trying hard to help people get affordable solar systems, but what we're asked to do makes it very stressful, and I know that, at least for me, I don't enjoy coming to work just to have everyone upset at me that I can't do the work of 3 people. Personally, this isn't the kind of place I want to work. I just want to be treated like a fellow human being, and I don't feel like that happens at the moment. I don't think this is a very family friendly environment. I get especially angry when I think about my supervisor, who consistently works 50-60 hours a week in order to make sure everything is getting done, but gets threatened every week with write-ups because we aren't meeting our goals. This is not a nice place to work, and I see that everyone around me is not treated very well. It is very frustrating to me.\\As far as the direction the company is going in, I really don't know enough about that to say. I don't know what kinds of things we're doing on the large scale, so I cannot say if I agree.

I receive information that is relevant to my particular job, but not too much past that. I mean, I'm aware when new offices are opened and things like that, but I guess I don't really know what our direction is. As far as my job, I know that I am able to perform well - my problem is that I am expected to do more work than I am able to do. I don't think that what is expected of us is reasonable, and I think that goals need to be scaled down to actually be reasonable without expecting people to work more than 40 hours per week (or whatever one is scheduled to work). I am certainly made aware of what is expected, but even when I try my hardest (as well as everyone around me), we are often unable to meet these expectations. This is my problem with this company. I understand that the reasons behind these big "quarterly goals" or other large goals are hidden from the average worker, but I don't think they should be. I think everyone should know why we're expected to work ridiculous hours or meet impossible expectations. As far as I know, it's just because someone wants to pad their pockets with my hard work. I try to give the benefit of the doubt, but it would certainly help if everyone was made aware of the reasoning behind these goals and expectations. I don't think it is a healthy environment where we are expected to do the impossible without knowing why or even having much incentive to do so.

I think I have said most of what is on my mind with the last two comments. I just hope that maybe this can open someone's eyes or change something. Anything. I just look around at my team and I want a better work environment for them and for myself, and I don't think we have that. I don't think anyone enjoys this. We want to be treated fairly and we want to be listened to. Our work is as important as anyone else's, so why aren't we treated like that? Is our input really not important? I'm just frustrated with the state of things here, and I don't think it's very fair to anyone. I appreciate the chance here to speak what is on my mind; I'm just skeptical that anything will come of this. I'm afraid that it will only bring further justification, but no solutions. Or worse, that it will go ignored because I disagree with the way things are done here. But, at least there is a chance that this will improve things, so here I am writing and hoping that something will change. Thanks for listening (or reading?), at the least.

I defiantly love my job and what I do, I work faithfully Monday through Saturday, I don't not have a lead in my warehouse but I have defiantly stepped up to the plate and I just don't feel appreciated. At times I am happy to come to work, But other times its a drag, if something goes wrong I feel like its my fault but when i Have things on track and going right I receive no credit for it. It's beginning to effect me mentally. so im not sure how much longer i will be able to last here.
Working for these company has been a life changing experience. Our training is one of a kind. It is also a great experience to be a part of as well as witness the growth.

I love Vivint Solar and everything that it stands for. I love the values because I always like to hold myself up to a standard. This company has taught me to embrace change & to be a leader in the revolution by helping others within the company. I know that the merger has created a lot of changes & has caused a lot of employees to flee because of the rumors about being laid off/fired. I only wish that someone would've spoken to us as a company to avoid those issues but we'll continue to be welcoming to the new hires. I enjoy working closely with other departments such as the local office, processing, interconnection,CAD, ESC, etc. I've always been that type of person to have a job that allows me to change someone else's world and I feel like Vivint Solar allows me to do that every day.

I enjoy being a CSM because I'm able to manage my time. I think work can be monotonous sometimes as well but it's really up to the CSM to motivate themselves or going out of their way to do something else that's effective & productive.

I've worked here for about  a year & half now. So much has changed in the company but it has always been positive growth. I enjoy being a part of this wonderful company and hopefully i'm able to have a career here in the future. I enjoyed training others about the positive effects this company has in this world & how they can be apart of it. \\I know that with the merger, everyone feels like there has been nothing but negative effects. For example, 2nd computer monitors being taken away, new hires receiving higher pay than those that were here longer, management favoritism, lack of inbound employees, techs getting laid off/fired out in the field, lack of care from the local office about the AB2FIN process, & issues with upgrades. I feel like with the merger, we need to come out with the positive benefits of doing that and refer back to the way things used to be. I guess just rebuilding that culture a year ago when it was welcoming, exciting, fun, hard-working, disciplined, & vibrant.

I would recommend Vivint Solar to friends and family as they take great care of their employees and provide a very fun environment. Clean energy is wonderful and I am pleased to be a part of it, it just is not my passion. It is just a decent job to me. I sit at a desk all day, I don't help people emotionally and spiritually in any way. That is why I don't jump out of bed to come to work.

I have learned what I have in this company because I have asked incessant questions and dug into department's processes. I think that breakdowns in how other departments function is a vital component of understanding that this company is greatly lacking. Cross training is a must if we are to work together. So much time is wasted because of ignorance to how other departments work. Every employee needs more detailed knowledge as a resource to succeed in this company.

I want to stress again the need for cross training company-wide. We are nearly ignorant of each other. We cannot be as effective as possible while we do not understand and help other departments. We need to be interconnected cogs of a clock, not separate wheels turning and surprised when we crash into each other. As interconnection, we dip our fingers in just about every department to receive PTO. I think the rest of the company would do well to do the same. If we can take a little time to learn from each other, we can save so much more time and sanity in the future.

I love what the company is doing. I truly believe that by helping people use sustainable energy that we are literally saving the planet. I have wonderful friends in the company but I am often by myself when I work so having that quick chat with a coworker or getting to know them is not very common, this is why I am not always excited to come to work. I don't invite family members to work where I do because I do not feel this is a long term job for most people my age. Not everyone can make enough here to support a family even though I am blessed to make just enough to do that. I am excited to come to work but for the reasons mentioned above I can lack excitement. This is one of those days, other days can be fantastic.

I do not feel that many of the employees around me care about their jobs as much as I do, some of them do but not very many. They do work, but I do not see loyalty, I feel that some of them come here for just a paycheck and that management does not talk with us enough to make them fee loyal. We are told basic things, but we do not have the tools built to know what we need to do in every situation. This is difficult to do for any job especially ours, but we need some answers that can stand so we do not always have to send an email to someone who might know and wait for replies. It seems that my managers are too busy to do what their job description states that they should be doing.\\Just to be clear, the managers around me are wonderful people but they are not involved with us the way that they should be.

When I interviewed with my manager I did not have the experience required to fit the "minimum requirements", because of a high recommendation he hired me anyway. He asked me how long that I planned to be here, I told him at least 2 years and I stand by that and I would love to work here much longer. I would hope that I can show my worth, and be here much longer than 2 years. \\I would really like to have a way to find out what is being done in our department and the direction it is going more often than once a year. I hear things here and there from people of what is going on but I almost never hear anything from management. It would be nice if employees could provide ideas in a group setting once in a while to help management do their jobs and possibly be able to help with projects to make managements job easier.\\It seems kind of odd to ask but having special assignments rather than more responsibilities would help make me and others feel more a part of this company and that we were actually needed as an individual. If I always feel like I could be replaced then I don't have much of a reason to want to stay here. I am sharing this not because it is a problem that I am having, it is because I have been given these responsibilities and I have seen the change that has occurred in my attitude towards this job.\\Thank you for your time Greg.

I love Vivint solar, but as the company grows there is a growing disconnect between who does what at corporate, and the sales team. Positions change and departments and policies change frequently, and it usually takes a while for us sales managers to hear about these changes.

I feel like we aren't told much of what's going on in the company with the whole merger and certain new rules. I know it's still in the process of going through , but I feel we should be kept up to date once in a while. After all this is our livelihood and job. We were told we would get a review on our performance and pay three months after the pay change and that still hasn't happend.

Why are we cutting down on hours and limiting everyone's work? I realize that cost is high and overtime is very expensive. But when we get no warning or a heads up it can really affect many employees. Is this also due to the merger ? Will we be able to work longer hours once everything goes through and we have more daylight? Thank you for hearing me out.

The company is moving in the right direction: \\I’ve worked for Vivint Solar for just a bit over a year now, and no matter what department I’m in there seems to a common thread: Lack of communication. I strongly believe in providing access to this alternative power source, Solar, to the masses, but I’m never sure what direction the company is moving towards – very little visibility. I’ve asked my direct supervisor where we’re at with the past goals: price per kWh, Mwh deployed, the merger, etc. and more times than not, I’m met with a lackluster answer – no fault to my supervision, he’s great, but with so little information being offered I find myself wondering if the company is sustainable and that worries me, because I really, really, really love my job as a CSM. This fits me and my personality well, and because I love what I do, that always outweighs the negative parts of the company – mainly, the lack of communication. \\This is just an opinion, and I don’t feel this is the forum to offer any suggestions for changes, just voicing my view.  Please know that by no stretch of the imagination an I disgruntled, I’m very happy with where I’m at, and what I do.

For younger employees maintaining the title of Vivint has a negative connotation and may deter younger talent based on a public stigma. Whenever anyone asks where you work they assume you are doing door to door sales.
Vivint Solar is an amazing company in need of a rebrand if they want to keep millennial talent.
I love this place! Let's take over the world.

I selected "disagree" in response to the question about the company moving in the right direction. The reason for this, is, I am not clear on what direction the company is moving towards. Meaning, it "feels" like the company is not certain of its' "end game" or ultimate purpose. And, if the company is operating with the end in mind, there is a lack of transparency. Is the goal of executive management simply to sell the company to the highest bidder? Or, is it to find a strategic partner (perhaps Sun Edison or another company) and fulfill the mission Vivint Solar set out to accomplish when I joined Vivint three years ago?

I am sincerely grateful for my career at Vivint Solar and the talented individuals I am able to work with and learn from on a daily basis. I fully recognize there is no company in existence that posses "corporate utopia," however, Vivint Solar is a pretty awesome place to work! I am proud to put on the Vivint Solar uniform (be it a jacket, shirt, or hat) and talk to everyone I meet about our company. The heart of any organization is its' people/employees--I believe Vivint Solar is second to none in regards to "people power". I have grown and learned more than I ever thought I would over the past three years at Vivint and Vivint Solar.I hope to continue to learn and progress in my next three years with the company!
Unsurprisingly, I feel some hesitation about what the future with SunEdison will bring. This is mostly due to (a) a lack of information/details and (b) its plummeting market value.

My team (Workforce) could only benefit from more technology. A third monitor would undoubtedly pay for itself with the boosted productivity it would provide. The move away from Microsoft Office concerns me, although my team has been allowed to continue to use it for now. It's hard for us to make as useful of reports and tools when our "customers" (other people in Customer Experience) don't have access to Office.\\I only hesitated on the commitment of my fellow employees because I see the stats of the CSMs and I hear all the other teams grumble about them. Of course it's easy to point fingers, but it seems like all the non-CSMs are very frustrated about CSMs working so little and being paid better than the other non-management employees in Customer Experience. To be fair, there are exceptions — some CSMs that work very hard and are great at their jobs!
Vivint Solar has been a great place to work for the past year and a half. I've made many friends, learned a lot, and realized that this is a company I plan on making a future with.

I feel that communication has always been excellent in my department. The necessary updates are received when they need to be, giving our work a clear meaning and purpose.\\I love that I am surrounded by people who love what they do and strive to make Vivint Solar the best it can be.

I just want to say that I am proud to be a part of the Vivint Solar family. I am very grateful to be doing what I love and for a company that is making a difference. Thank you for making the opportunities given to me possible.

I really think we are providing a necessary service to our communities. While I am not totally convinced that man-made global warming is a real threat, I am totally convinced that putting millions of tons of carbon into the air is not a good thing. I also am convinced that we save people money by switching to solar and help affect the marketplace to lower the cost of power for everyone. This is a very good thing. I believe in our leadership to make the right and hard decisions to make our company the very best. I look forward to being a part of this company for a very long time.

I think the only thing I have trouble with is with all the bugs in IT concerning all the progress in our software to keep us up to date with the best applications. They affect us in the field in a negative way. However I know that they are just growing pains and we in the field are working through it in a positive way. I feel that the company has gotten better in the way we do business every quarter, and speed of execution and work flow has gotten better as we have kept working on breaking through the bottlenecks.

I really think that we need to improve the on-boarding process for new hires. I feel we throw them out into the field without comprehensive training and I have seen much better salespeople with more experience not last long due to getting frustrated with the process. I also think we need to be more patient with first year salespeople. Knocking on doors is a very specialized form of selling and it takes time to adjust and get comfortable with being so independent. I think we push a little too hard for results and the pressure forces new salespeople to not put in the time on the doors. They need some time to get experience on the doors. I think we lose too many potentialialy great people because we put to much pressure too soon. Just like taking professional sport rookies and demanding too much from them too early. We need to have a great training organization to develop all people to reach their full potential. I don't think we are there yet. What I do know is that everyone I work with is very conscious of the problems and are working hard to overcome. I am so proud to be a part of this company.

This company seems to be better in theory than execution.  There is a very real communication problem between the different operations departments, between the field and corporate, and between operations and the rest of corporate. The company seems fragmented in the way it operates, and it seems to be a very real glass ceiling for us.

Vivint Solar could be significantly more green in the way it operated. I see lots of wasted paper, styrofoam, and plastic on a daily basis. I also think the company could be much "greener" in the vegetable/nutritional sense of the word, there should not be muffins, soda, and chips laying around everywhere. Why is our company so obsessed with constantly providing copious amounts of soda and junk food to its employees? Green should start from the inside out. We should be working to create an environmentally friendly atmosphere/consciousness in the work place. There should be plants everywhere. We should be politically involved in environmental issues. I think Vivint Solar needs to start walking the walk, employees love flaunting the fact that we are a "green company" but we are not a green company in so many ways; we just have a green product. There is a difference.

Thanks for the opportunity!  I work in the Inside Sales Department.  I really enjoy the work environment at Vivint Solar.   The people in our department, the management, the product, are all great.  I am frustrated/disappointed with the financial compensation.  We were told in our interviews we would make significantly more money than we are making.  We are making less than half what we were told.  Maybe after the merger with Sun Edison things will change for the better with compensation, but for now it's very low.  I also realize that we are a relatively new department and things are very fluid with change.

I was asked to take on a higher position in the company but was not offered what I felt even approached competitive pay to do that work. I have strong credentials for what I was being promoted to and felt that it was not appropriate. I turned down the promotion. I was still asked to do everything for the new position but was told that they could not pay me more to do it. It was so disrespectful to the work I have already put into the company that I cannot recommend the company to others and do not plan to stay much longer then to find another job. I care for the company and want it to succeed and know I could help with that in any position I hold her as I am committed to doing quality work but it makes a poor work environment to be disrespected so much.

Most of this is just my aversion to desk jobs.  I love solar energy and what it will do for the planet, but working in an office, this one especially in ways, though due to who works here and how they do things, is like being a cow in a slaughterhouse.

We receive an update on the company every month or so, but I feel like we've been left in the dark about the gigantic merger.  My supervisor has been pettily ignoring anything but direct face-to-face conversation with me, which I don't feel comfortable with because I feel judgment towards me coming from her all the time.  She knows I am leaving my job on the 18th and has given up on our coworker relationship since October, even blatantly ignoring a lengthy email I took the trouble to send her regarding our issues.  I know that I earned temporary aggression from her for being a late a lot in a short period of time earlier this year, but nothing on this level.  I hate having to come into work and sit with her watching over me, I feel like she is constantly looking for ways to get me out of my job because she hasn't talked to me in weeks.  Maybe just stress the responsibility of not being petty when hiring Supervisors, that's much too high of a position to give to someone who will act this way.

Since i have been here there have been a lot of empty promises. When Steve Roy came on we as supervisors were told that with the growth that was happening int he company that we would all be managers as things grew. When those manager positions came up there was only one supervisor that was made a manager and the rest of the managers where hired from outside the company. Very frustrating to come to work everyday with that in mind.

Coming from a sales perspective.\I have a strong feeling that in many areas corporate doesn't have a very good understanding of what it takes most effieciently generate accounts, most effieciently progress them to install, PTO and beyond.  \In my view we have built this machine the best we could with the information and experience that was available but in so doing the process has been broken up and compartmentalized.  The system does work but not as effienciantly as it should.  The workflow between the different departments in many cases is difficult.   \I think the problem with making the changes that need to be made is that many Corp leaders who don't really understand the entire process from A-Z fight the changes that would streamline the business because changes may effect their jobs.\It's interesting that there isn't an attitude of continuous improvement and the attitude of trying to do things better than has been done in the past.\I love Vivint and solar but it is hard to sell to the very best of my ability when I know for example many of our customers are being billed on an estimated basis because of Internet trouble or a bad envoy.   when the system is underproducing, thus overbilling the customer.  \I'v ran into a few homes were only half of the panels are producing or all of them.  I'm serious... And we're billing them or not billing them at all.  So much lost $ because we really don't monitor this stuff.  And if there's a billing error it takes an enormous amount of effort to fix.  I'm not trying to be negative.\My recommendation is that we really need to clarify what we are doing and what's absolutely essential to accomplish it and cut out and remove everything else.  \Another quick example of the disconnect I see is the creation of sales materials.  Aka sales slicks.  It seems like those that have never sold an account or only have a superficial knowledge of the process are the ones creating the tools to sell the product.  It's not how it should be

Often it's just as hard to sell and install an account as it is to navigate the account through Vivint's ever complicated and shoddy systems.  Sorry if that's harsh.  I know we can do better.  I certainly can do better.\I have seen improvement from Vivint in the last year which is why I'm still here

While my department isn't directly affected I am concerned by the pressure and disdain given to many at corporate by our sales team. My 2.5 years working for Vivint Solar has shown how disrespectful some can be at times and I cannot see that any effort has been given to change this.

While we do receive company updates I feel like information has been lacking regarding the Sun Edison merger. I am concerned that their falling stock value has had a profound influence on the deal and it makes me and others worried. I would love to hear more news about that.\\The team I work for manages our scheduling software. We are severely limited in improvements that we can make to the software to improve our scheduling processes. We need development invested in such a crucial aspect and more staff working directly on the development. Due to this lack of developmental support our team is often viewed negatively as being lacking rather than being seen as working as effectively as possible with the tools given. Improvements would allow for better company efficiency and customer satisfaction.

I really enjoy the work I do for Vivint Solar and feel that the work is valuable. I'm not ashamed to work for this company, but also not overly proud as I think we still have room for improvement when it comes to our reputation.

While I believe the majority of employees are hard-working and committed to doing quality work, we do hire an abundance of college students and there are many in that group who seek to do the minimum required since this is not their intended career. I myself am a college student and do know many here who strive to do the most they can, but also see many who do not care to try their hardest.

Vivint Solar is a good company to work for. They have a lot of good qualities when it comes to how they treat employees. There are some draw backs and business practices I am not overly found of but overall I am content with my job.

I feel like I have been able to succeed in the positions I am put in. I have always had the resources I needed to succeed. I do run into frustrations when people don't put in the same work ethic or effort into there jobs as I have been putting into mine. I also find it frustrating I am compensated the same as an employee not producing nearly the quantity or the quality of work I am producing. However I am and have been recognized for my hard work.

Thank you, I appreciate my job and the opportunity I have had at the company. I hope to continue to learn and grow hear at Vivint Solar. I do see the company growing and addressing a lot of the issues they do have which I appreciate the company's ability to adapt and correct poor processes and such.

The company has a great service/product and is on an excellent trajectory in regards to growth, senior leadership, and improving our delivery. However, as much as the company does for the employees (thank you very much) I would much rather have the company listen to me and my feed back then give me free soda. A few of us are over qualified for the positions that we hold, but continue on because we believe that we can work our way upward in the company and, hopefully, provide insite from someone who came from the trenches - as it were. I think it would behoove the company to find these individuals and ask for their input on decisions that affect the bottom echelons of workers here and how to improve processes, over come obstacles, and motive employees. Many of our ideas are cheap or free and would be very helpful. As it is, I feel appreciated, but ultimately interchangeable. - Kyle Vanderniet

My coworkers and I all know in a vague sense that our purpose and goals are to progress customers toward PTO while providing a quality customer service experience. I know that we are supposed to co-ordinate with the local office, customers, and corporate departments to accomplish this.  However, as a phenomenally growing company resources are limited and instructions, training, and well formed expectations are either non-existent or are likely to become quickly outdated or obsolete as the company changes and job duties remain somewhat fluid. This leads to employees being overwhelmed and trying to do an adequate job for most of their accounts instead of superlative job for all their accounts. I know, and see, that some of the factors that contribute to this are being addressed as quickly as possible and that the "top brass" want out condition to improve but, the work force is simply stretched too thin and departments too antagonistic for employees to set their expectation above anything than mediocrity.

I truly believe that all levels of management only want what is best for the company and that even the lowest level of employees want to be able to do a good job. I also know that when people don't feel they are able to achieve that or are at lest don't have access to the tools to do their work to a high level of satisfaction they begin to lower their own expectations and frustration rises. I also know that most employees want to effect positive change around the company and improve communication and work flow between departments. However, no one wants to be left holding the hot potato of blame and so point all their fingers at each other department. When in truth - everyone is understaffed for the growth of the company  and the vast majority of employees (down here) are not yet seasoned. The benefits that the company provides makes all of us very happy and make us want to continue to come to work, but the difficulties in our daily processes is a never ending source of consternation. \\There are some simple changes that would make a world of difference using only the resources we have on hand. There are many at all levels of the company, but especially the bottom, who would love the chance to present ideas for change and betterment of the company. Most importantly though, many aspects of the process are unique to states or even individual offices - allowing small amounts of approved diversion would be immensely beneficial to moral and productivity.

I've been with the company for a while.  I believe morale is at an all-time low.  Much of that has to do with uncertainty in the industry, low performance of the company in recent months, and the looming SunEdison acquisition.  It's my belief that the low morale leads to lower performance, which perpetuates a "non-virtuous circle".  That said, I'm confident that the company and its leadership can succeed - we have a lot of work to do.

I'm 50/50 on the company moving in the right direction. I'm not sold on SunEdison acquiring us. I've gone through an acquisition and I've had friends go through acquisitions and it never seems to work out well for the company that got acquired. After the acquisition, things seem to move along "business as usual" for 8-12 months and then downsizing starts. I know the company needs to look long-term for things like financing options and an acquisition could open more doors that but still the thought of downsizing is in the back of a lot of minds.\\I currently wouldn't encourage family/friends to work here until we see how things pan out with SunEdison.
