If that wasn't on the table then I would for sure encourage anyone to work here.

There's no communication between what we need to do to be successful in a quarter or stay informed on what is going on in the company. I feel like I know somewhat of what is going on in our department but when it comes to company wide successes or failures I have no idea.

I appreciate the opportunity to share some of my thoughts. Some of my thoughts were negative but when we identify the negative we know where we need to focus. When we start focusing to improve on those areas other areas of improvement will be made aware.\\Overall I love working at this company. It honestly doesn't even feel like work because I love what I do and I'm blessed to be able to do something that I love. However, just because I love it doesn't mean that there aren't frustrations and pain points that come up frequently. Trying to fix frustrations and pain points is one of the reasons I love it. When I look at where we are now and where we can be 5 years from now...I get a huge smile on my face.

My first year working for vivint solar was great, I felt like we were making a difference and I felt like it was my company too. Now with the merge I feel like it is all about cost per watt and the whole "tribe" mentality is out the window. I agree that we should work safe but feel that to be fired with a second write up is pretty harsh.I have seen alot of turnover of good workers who did alot for the company and now they are gone.It makes me nervous for my job instead of having a positive outlook.

When I started working for vivint  I installed the electrical portion of the job. Iam a certified journeyman electrician. I recieved a $50.00 monthly phone allowance to use my phone for company purposes.I was moved into a lead service tech position and lost my phone allowance.I use my phone for my job now more than I did before but I have been told that my position receives no phone allowance or company cellphone. Iam using my personal cellphone to conduct vivint business and am not being compensated for it at all. When I told my OM that I was going to leave my personal cellphone at home I was told I would probably lose my job for doing so. Not cool

We are providing a product and services which helps families save money while contributing to reducing the impact of climate change. I have a socially redeeming job that I can be proud of with a company that is having a positive influence.

We pay for our own marketing materials as 1099 contractors. Signs , flyers, welcome kits, business cards are not readily available. There is no internal marketing support for kiosk, trade shows, business events. Those are at our own expense, not within the reach of most employees starting out.

I am really pleased to see the new directives that are providing systematic training to new employees. When I first arrived there was little formal support on how to fill out contract and move accounts through the system. I can see that is changing and it's a really positive effort.\\I recently have had two already signed accounts cancel because of our internet reviews. After talking with the DMs here in my office I know more about how to deal with those situations. At the same time I believe the company could do more with "reputation monitoring" services that would manage any negative comments with a professional and appropriate response that reduces the negative impact of any such comments or reviews.

I moved out here to Utah to work for Vivint Solar and I really like the atmosphere and culture. In fact I  only recommend the job to select friends that I feel would add to that and would actually benefit the company.

Despite my time here at Vivint solar I feel like we didn't learn anything other than new ways to navigate through SalesForce to help us in the CSM role. I wasn't taught how to do reports or things that the pilot teams learned or found to be helpful when creating Excel Spreadsheets to help them keep track of everything. It was more of okay here are your accounts go ahead and assign your name to the accounts and email all of your customers and good luck on figuring out how to be successful in moving those accounts forward. Coming from a specialty team things had changed and were more detailed and so it was a struggle just trying to understand what to look for and how to resolve the account to get it moving forward again. Things would have been smoother if I had known what to look for and what I am going to be required to do to help that account get their gears moving forward again before having the customer on the phone asking and we're just faking it until we make it.

I think it's so very cool to be not just part of a job but part of a revolution. A revolution for change for cleaner, greener energy and it just makes so much sense to try and help spread solar all over to tap in to that solar energy that is abundantly available. It almost seems like it's a no brainer that solar is definitely a key in the direction to not just lowering our CO2 emissions but a smart choice to use the solar rays that would other wise be unused which is why I am glad that Vivint Solar is teaming up and joining Sun Edison in this massive cause and dream. This Thanksgiving weekend I shared with my younger brother my vision of how I see a day where everywhere you look rooftops are covered in some sort of prolific solar technology all around the world. So it's cool and even empowering to think that I am more than just an employee at a company, I am a ripple in this wave of change. However it is a struggle to be so overwhelmed with all the work as a CSM and the constant minor issues that seem to just be shrugged to the side or given the quick band-aid treatment. Since I was 17 when my parents got APEX I was amazed at the reps, customer service and the quick response time from Vivint. But now I don't talk to my neighbors about getting Vivint Security or Solar. I like the home-automation and the solar but I feel like the Company I know is now more about numbers which is important for growth and stocks. However with my southern roots I want less of a New Yorker attitude and more focus on quality and great customer experience. I want our amazing company to focus on cleaning up what accounts we do have and then striving to move forward strong again. It's like we're trying to win a sprint while also trying to tie our shoes during the race. I want us to get our running shoes on first and then run a marathon. I feel like it's a company where the attitude is "just push it through" and it's frustrating that I have lost trust in a company I love to the point where I don't want to push, sell and convince family and friends to get it because I don't want to infringe my relationship with them on potentially having them be over promised, no show appointments, constant work order rejections, long delay of getting to submitting interconnection after trusting me how highly I talk of the company over all the bad reviews to be disappointed. Maybe I am just ignorant to corporations and I have too high of expectations for my company and this is just how things are in large businesses but I refuse to have that attitude of "that's just how it is" and that is why my attitude has gone from strongly agree to just agree to my commitment because I have just been thinking of maybe taking the time to go study abroad since I think I need a break from this since I am not as Happy coming to work as I used to be. So I apologize to just vent and let it all out on how my role is frustrating on accounts not moving forward and how it's annoying that Work Orders missing or things just not getting done and etc. causing a issues in having a great customer service since I know it's a great company and the CSM role problems are just one other thing to what everyone else is dealing with and the many stressful things that you have to deal with however you asked me to be completely honest and to not hold back. Otherwise I have nothing but good things to say about the company and I look forward to when Vivint Solar has it's foundation down and solid and things start to move more smoothly which is why I keep helping and moving forward to help accomplish.

I love working for Vivint Solar. I love that we are helping clean the air and power people. It's hard to feel a part of the 'bro vibe' as a woman in the workplace. I get sick of seeing how much money is spent on 'swag' and incentives for sales offices when we don't hit numbers.

Only issue I have is being forced to work on the roof in the rain and having to shovel the roof when it's covered in snow it's just not safe at all it should be against company policy to get on a roof in those conditions

There is some disconnect between middle management and the rest of our department. The exchange of information is scarce and when it is delivered it is met with animosity and difficulty. Change is not being well received. Accountability is low. Even though upper management is making requests to enforce department standards, the middle management is failing to follow through. Morale on my team is very low and we are on a sinking ship. My fellow coworkers do not recognize how great of a job they have here. It's frustrating and saddening. I wish I knew how to solve these issues.

I really love this company and wish that I could give it higher marks. I think we are so close to becoming the best solar company in the world. Unfortunately I have seen how bad our operations and communication is from corporate to the field. We have really messed up a lot and created some very upset customers. It's a very low percentage of customers that go through the whole process without some sort of major failure along the way on our part. Our process has been so bad that it has been almost impossible for me to get referrals and create repeated business. Because of those reasons I can't give our company high marks. We shoot ourselves in the foot with our lack of communication and lack of ownership on progressing accounts. We are headed in the right direction with the CSM program but it's going to take a while for that to be where it needs to be. I love this company and I'm working hard every day to make it the best.
The only information I get from the company is during the Monday conference call. I really don't get any new information from my direct supervisor.
I think we have very strong level four and 5 Leaders in this company. Especially on the sales side. The operations side is the part of the company that needs the most improvement.
For as mush as I have made this company my number one priority and worked incredibly hard and have been given more big responsibilities I do not feel I am compensated enough, or appreciated at all.

I am routinely asked to go above and beyond(Supply chain side) and the command structure in my area is not at all supportive or appreciative of how much there is to do on a daily basis. I would strongly urge you to re-consider some of your lower level management for the warehouses.

The work this company is doing is something I have long been passionate about. I have helped to influence legislative action in Arizona and I truly care about this industry. That said: I'm on the verge of leaving this company due to poor management.

I mostly said that I neither agree nor disagree with these statements for two reasons: 1) the statements are vague and 2) there is a log in limbo which makes it difficult to be excited. I'm not sure I know enough about what's happening to know if the company is moving in the right direction or not. I want to be committed to the company and be excited to come to work, but I feel like things are a little directionless right now and we aren't working toward goals. We are working to put out fires which isn't very inspiring.

I feel like I never know what's going on and if I ask, I don't get much. I get the feeling the company wants to be great, but is floundering. I have resources like software and such to do my job, but I don't have the understanding and the buy in from the company to do my job effectively.

I sincerely want to help the company succeed. Instead, I feel like I spend most of my time processing orders for things that I don't understand. My limited involvement makes it difficult to produce a product that I know is going to work and make people successful. It limits my sense of purpose in what I do. I look back at when I was hired and I feel like I was asked to help shape Vivint Solar's future and, instead, I kind of feel like I'm getting dragged behind the horse.

I really enjoy this company. There are some frustrations that make the job difficult. For example, cads take over a week on average, while other companies like legacy and solar city have designs with in a few hours. \\Also, Apollo causes more problems than it's worth it seems. PPAs are constantly rejected or not recieved. \\Software updates are too frequent and seem to cause confusion. \\I love Vivint solar.

This is a stellar company with incredible vision. I love being a pet of it. There are a few small things that I think would allow this company to absolutely take off...\\1.) quicker cad designs- 1-2 business days max.  It seems that the sales managers and upper management on sales side are the only ones with a sense of urgency. The cad designers and structural need some urgency. \\2.) Apollo needs to work all the time or it needs to be replace. Resubmitting documents or docs not being recieved by corporate is an ongoing issues. \\This company is phenomenal. I love it and am blessed to be here.

I am a bit upset that I keep getting tasks added to my daily responsibilities, but my pay remains the same. I wouldn't mind having a task or two added, but my pay has remained the same for 11 months, and I'm constantly getting new tasks added to my duties.

Greg, I feel like Vivint Solar has several major problems. I have worked here for 2 years now and have seen several changes in the company. I trust that this survey is totally anonymous so without  revealing my identity I will tell you that my current position involves double checking the electrical work done by our installers and electricians. I have been doing this for about 7 months now and I can honestly say the electrical mistakes I have seen our electricians and installers make are scary but not as scary as the lack of concern the upper management has concerning them. Without going into too much detail about the specific mistakes it is suffice to say that they are blatant fire hazards which could result in death or serious injury to the customer. Some mistakes I see put the customer in risk of electric shock ( which can also cause death or serious injury) if their solar system were to be struck by lightning.   \\Now what I would expect to happen when a company finds out about these problems is they go back to EVERY home that has a problem and fix it immediately. Unfortunately what happens here at Vivint Solar is we discover the problem and decide to set a date about a month before we discovered the problem and say "if this account was installed after this date we will go back out and fix it". This is great except what about the other customers potentially in  the hundreds that still have these hazards installed on their homes? Are we really going let their lives be in danger just so we can make money off their systems because their system was installed before the ridiculous date we set going 1 month back?\\WE SHOULD GO FIX EVERY HOME! I understand that it will cost a lot of money and manpower and time to do this but IT'S THE RIGHT THING TO DO!!!!!!!!!!!! \We need exceptional training and standards for our electricians in the field as well as our installers. If you say we already do I say you're sadly mistaken. The amount of simple mistakes I see on a daily basis that have the potential to become serious problems is concrete evidence to me that we definitely don't have exceptional training and standards for our employees in the field. \\Vivint Solar's current state of mind is Push accounts to PTO NO MATTER WHAT so we can start making money! We really don't care if their system was installed correctly or not, we don't care about the safety of our customers we just want their money. If it passes permitting it must be safe right??????? \\Because of this I am not proud to work here, The only joy I get from my job is knowing the work I have done for that day helped some of our customers be safer in their homes by catching mistakes we have made and taking steps to get them fixed.\\I would never let anyone in my family or my friends get solar panels from Vivint Solar, EVER.\\Greg, Have you looked our company up on the better businesses bureau?  I have and guess what? We are a complete joke! \\Lastly I would not recommend working for us to any friends or family because our pay is substantially lower than other companies in the industry. I still haven't gotten the raise I was promised once I moved to my new position. I understand that this is not anyone's fault because of the merger but I honestly don't expect to get that raise regardless if the merger goes through or not.\\\I would love to see our companies vision change from getting tons and tons of accounts installed to focusing on installing them right. Who would you rather get solar from, the biggest solar company in the industry or  the company who is known for installing systems correctly and safely? \\Quality over quantity.\\\I really hope this wasn't to harsh!

I am sure you have heard about the tragic shooting at an office building in San Bernardino toady. \I think I speak for everyone when I say we would feel a lot safer if we had armed guards at EVERY building at EVERY entrance with their own little desks 1 hour before and after regular business hours in Orem ( as well as Lehi). The Orem building has the canyon park security officers but they are not armed...I don't think they even have pepper spray and I rarely see them in our building.  It would be great to make sure every door that has a badge reader is locked at all times too. I know here in Orem the internal doors don't lock and require a badge until after 7 pm.

It is tough to tell if the company is moving in the right direction.  Is the buyout happening?  Is it not happening?  There needs to be a major push towards quality because having "numbers" being the most important thing has brought about serious quality issues.  \\Also, we don't hold anyone accountable.  If we find a crew has cut a corner and caused us to be called back to a job for a quality issue, they should be given the final warning that the next time, they are gone.  Quality, Quality, Quality.  I asked a CSL today our percentage of leaks.  He said 20-30 %.  That is unacceptable.

We used to have quarterly webinars to stay in the loop.  We then missed one followed by the announcement of the acquisition.  Now we do not know if the sale is a go or not.  I have no idea how the company is doing and where we are headed. I used to (4 months ago) feel like I knew.  I have no idea what our quarterly goals are.  I never saw an email or a video in an email to explain the goals.

We need to emphasize quality or we will lose "word of mouth" references.  We have homes in MA that have panels on them for months and the electrical finish has not been done.  Very bad for business.  If you did not pay salesman until the electrical finish was done this would not occur.\\Please bring back the quarterly webinar.  I have no idea if the company is going under or if the sale is a go.\\We need loss prevention.  I am a former police officer and now a safety tech for Vivint.  There is enough fraud in Vivint that I could single handedly save the company 10 times a loss prevention salary.\\Perhaps limiting crews to one install a day would fix the quality issue.  Or, maybe holding crews/foreman/employees accountable for quality issues. \\We need to hold the employees accountable for the equipment they use.  We need to make each employee sign out their tools and safety equipment.  Otherwise, they lose it, sell it, steal it, then ask for replacement and they get it.  This is bad for business.\\There needs to be more guidance for employees on how and when to service their vehicles.  Vehicles go 20,000 miles without oil changes because nobody cares.  There needs to be a system in place to promote and guide vehicle service. \\Feel free to contact me and let me know if you need anything else from me.  I love Vivint, I believe in what we are doing, and I hope we succeed! Ben Williams Benjamin.williams@vivintsolar.com

I've worked here for 2 years and have seen an enormous amount of growth in the company. I feel there is a disconnect between the teams that work here at Corporate and those out in the field. It seems there is a lot of focus on Sales Reps, which is understandable considering we don't have a job to do if they're not out selling. However, too often, I see accounts that get installed without proper documentation being signed by the customer then received and approved by our Processing Department. There are always calls or emails coming in from sales reps that basically say "can't you just push this forward?". It isn't a big secret that they receive commission when an account is installed, and for whatever reason, they look for someone here to make an exception for them so that they can hit their numbers forgetting that if those exceptions are constantly made, we risk damaging our relationships with utility companies, investors, and ultimately customers (current and potential customers). What may seem like a small favor to a sales rep for our Processing or Customer Experience teams to move an account forward without all the proper steps being completed first, has the potential to a huge mess that Processing or Customer Experience has to clean up...and often WITHOUT the help of the sales rep.

The Corporate Quality Assurance team started in February of this year. From February through July, we were on a streak of getting problem accounts moving forward. In that short amount of time, we were able to aid in getting just over 44 mW deployed. There were several different projects that we worked on and our work was noticed. In the Summer, it was announced that our team was basically being dissolved and that the new Customer Success Manager role would take on the responsibilities we once had to streamline the post-install to PTO process. What was and still is unclear is why a team that was able to achieve that much in a short amount of time was being dissolved so soon. Each of the 8 people on our team was given the normal workload that an entire team would handle (For Example: On my own, I had 500 accounts to review and push forward on a weekly basis. 2 team members had 700 on their individual lists, and another team member had close to double my number of accounts). Our very first week, we were given a project that contained close to 4,000 accounts that needed to be reviewed individually and placed in a bucket. Once we started on the project, we were informed that we had until that Friday morning to complete it. In order to meet that deadline, 5 members of the team worked their normal Thursday shift, then stayed to work through the night until the start of their normal shift the next day. In those few months with that original team, we constantly worked to build and improve relationships with those that we worked with both in the field and here at Corporate. In August, our team moved under the Processing Department. This happened shortly after the announcement of the SunEdison Merger and the transition from Customer Support to Customer Success. We feel a great sense of support here working under Myles Taylor and Malachi Hughes. However, because our moved happened in the middle of  other big changes in the company, we are still trying to get a good grasp on what our role as a team should be doing. There is so much good potential with what we can accomplish. I've seen it first hand. And I continue to see the great work that my team is able to do. Although there are times when our work seems underappreciated and our potential overlooked, my team continues to put out quality work and make the best of what they're given.

I absolutely love where I work and what I do here. I appreciate the team I am on and want to see it succeed. I feel like there is definitely a need for our Corporate Quality Assurance team and with the right structure and overall support, there is no doubt in my mind that we can be a great asset to the company like we were in the beginning of the year.\This is a great place to work! I've been here for 2 years and have enjoyed it so far!

Greg I'm all in buddy! I don't know what's happening with SunEd and frankly I don't care. We(SWOT) are gonna fill this place to the rafters with reps that are hungry and determined to take #GOSolar to the next level. I couldn't be more confident in what you, Chance, and the SR leadership is doing and can't wait to see where we are gonna take this thing! 31G and beyond!!

I feel like most things in theory differ dramatically from reality, this company has a great idea, product and concept, but the current reality of the company is far different from the wonderful theory. There are many good things about this company, a few great things but also a lot of negative ones. Although I am passionate about what we are trying to accomplish, there are tremendous opportunities to improve the way we are currently accomplishing it.

The chain of leadership for me seems to constantly try to sell me on that the processes aren't that bad. They often compare our office to other offices and tell us how good we have it. They also compare our company to other solar companies and say they experience the same things. As a sales rep my ideal mentality is to get things done and not make excuses but if the example set by my direct superiors is to constantly make excuses for why things are the way they are and not have any idea on when/how/or why they are going to get better, it allows me to lose site of the goal.

Greg,\\I'm a sales rep, my feelings about the job and about the company change frequently. Some days I wake up and feel as though I am able to take on the world. I process through whatever accounts I have and send emails or make phone calls to get the accounts to whatever the next step is in the process. Then I go out to area and knock. Some people tell me "no," other tell me "not right now," and on a good day one or two people tell me "yes." After a few hours of knocking, if I have a design to show or someone to follow up with, I'll go do that. Then when I'm done in area I'll go home and reflect on my day and analyze where I could have improved or done something different. That would describe a good productive day.\\Unfortunately lately those types of days are few and far between. The types of days I've been having lately (6-12 months) focus so much less on customer facing opportunities and creating/selling accounts and mainly on trying aimlessly to put out fires with current accounts leading up to install and/or accounts that have already been installed. The amount of time, energy, effort and focus that goes into maintaining accounts and trying to keep them happy greatly outweighs my time spent generating new business. \\The ESC process has been a nightmare in my office. Months go by after install before the ESC is done. I've been trying to give my customers realistic expectations and if they need an ESC I've had to start prepping them for a 6-12 month install to PTO wait time. The process from install to PTO hasn't been very smooth either. All too often after install issues arise causing a delay in PTO. From missing IWOs/EWOs, to the processing department not being able to upload documents in a timely fashion, to everything being ready for inspection but the account just sitting for weeks before inspection is scheduled. Frequent phone calls I get from customers sound like this, "Hey, I've been installed for over a month and no one has reached out to me to let me know what's going on, I was told I would get a phone call or email telling me to turn my system off in three days and I never got that phone call. When is the inspection going to happen? When will my system be working? Why is it that it seems like you guys work really fast to get the panels up on my roof but after that it seems like you don't care about is anymore?" When I get these types of calls it zaps my motivation, my drive and mostly my desire to go out and do MY JOB, which is selling accounts and taking them to install. Me not out working and creating accounts and in turn not installing as many accounts as I used to is something that I take responsibility for. Personally searching for reasons and answers to why I'm not out working and installing as many accounts per week/month/quarter/year as I am capable of, has led me back to the same spot and asking my self the same questions time and time again. "Does the company really care about the customer once the panels are installed?" "Even though I personally am doing everything in my power to give my customers a great experience and representing a company that provides a great product, are the processes of the company going to get better than they are now?" "Am I a good salesman for a company that has lost sight of how important it is to continue to provide a great experience for the customer?"\\As of now I am not ready to leave the company, but I contemplate it weekly and I am not alone. The company has so much potential marginal benefit that is being lost from unhappy customers. It's something I battle with customers on a regular basis. A company is only as good as it's employees and the culture they foster. We have really good people who work for this company, but as a whole, as an aggregate, I feel the company is severely under performing on its promises. I believe this is what's leading to the answers on this survey. \\Greg, if you actually do read this, I appreciate you taking the time to hear my coments and concerns. Thanks.
Proud vivint employee, lots of opportunities to grow.
Need more information status about where  the company is heading

I understand that number are very important and that is understandable; but often times the number that are reflect on Vivint Solar's FB Page do not match up with the number we have here in the Processing/Interconnection Department; which often times becomes misleading as the correct number are not projected. And also I feel as though all the rewards go out to the sales rep who are knocking on doors getting those sales; which don't get me wrong I am grateful for that because I wouldn't have a job. I often feel that the communication between this company is quite possibly the worst that I have ever seen. And nobody ever seems to be on the same page which can be frustrating when it comes to setting clear visions and goals. Lately it feels as though often times there are certain people on the team who cut corners to get ahead and when told by upper management no action is being taken which makes it difficult to stay motivated when people keep cutting corners and nothing is being done.

I know that there are some things that we are not able to know because they are still in the process of getting approved or are still rolling out; but if there was better communication that would be much appreciated. And it would be wonderful if when things arise or problems arise if people would just admit the mistake and then move forward instead of trying to point everyone else out. Part of being on a team or more over in this company we are all apart of this big plan to accomplish the 31G; but if there is no communication and everyone is pointing the finger at everyone else and not taking responsibility and owning up to their mistakes we won't get very far. And honestly, it would just be nice to get the recognition from upper management or whomever that everyone besides the sales reps and those out in the field are doing a great job. We would love some of those amazing perks as well!
Many changes...individuals must be emotionally stable to stay focused on end result
If we take care of the employees the company & customers will benefit

We need to be More Honest with the Customers !
I Love working for this company that's Why I haven't Left Becuase I Believe in Never Giving up just Becuase Life throws us a couple Punches !

There seems to be a lot of uncertainty with how this merger will affect day to day operations. Daily learning and growing with a company I feel finally recognizes my hard work and dedication to our craft. How do I share this motivation with others and help them grow?
I have work at NY01 Since 2013. In those 2 years the company has gotten better and more structured. What ever happens in the future can only make Vivint Solar greater.
I find that installs are most important. I nave two accounts that are almost one year old, still no PTO. I have loss credibility, referrals, friendship, and Vivint Solar has loss millions..

Dedication, support, and follow through should be the ultimate to our customers. Vivint Solar should be the leader in the industry. We have failed and let too many customers fall through the cracks. I enjoy working here much more than I thought I would, and the more I see how the business model compares with other solar companies, the more I like it. Most of the uncertainty about expectations and resources stems from the aforementioned lack of communication from CAD, which sometimes leaves me feeling like the way we're training new hires is going to be obsolete by the time they get upstairs because we aren't told when things change.\\It's been a while since we got an update on SunEdison.

I feel that as a team lead in the Interconnection department, myself and my teammates do not feel nearly as recognized as other departments and sales teams are. As you can tell by my very moderate answers, I'm neither strongly passionate nor angry about much. I'm very middle of the road for a reason; I have mixed feelings about working here and how I really feel about this company. As a whole company, it seems like we're moving in the right direction in terms of product but not in how we are operating internally.

With the merger, it's hard to get any clear indication of what we're doing and why. I'm a CAD facilitator. You can know who I am. \When I got this position I came from being a CAD designer making around $11/hour to $13.50. For a week it seemed like a big raise, until CAD re-structured pay and CAD designers then made $12.50. I was barely making more than the new hires I was training! And a dollar less than Lead Designers, who make $14.50. It was a slap in my face that I was making so much less than lead designers. My manager, couldn't do anything about it at that point, nor could he change anything later when a Lead Designer became a new facilitator and kept his $14.50/hour pay. A person who just started my job was making (and is still making) a dollar more than me!\Months later, when a new CAD position was created (a Training Lead), a position that would in many ways be below my own, the pay for that position would be $14.50/hour. Someone on a lower level would be making more than me! Of course I applied to that position, and when the pay of the new position was brought up to Steve Roy, he said no to a raise for my position. I got the training lead position, but before I could take it HR was upset that CAD made a new position, so the position was cancelled. (Ask yourself if you'd go crazy at this point.)\So I was back making still the same pay as when I began the position, still less than a Lead Designer, and less than the person who started after me. And I've talked to CAD supervisors, and I could even go back to being a basic CAD designer and make the same pay I'm doing now. Isn't that insane?\\Then my manager assured me that when the new Director of Training came in, he'd be able to offer raises because he was no longer under Steve Roy. That didn't happen. Maybe it will, with some of the training re-structure, but who knows. I like my job, but all this hasn't given me a whole lot to be confident in. I'm hopeful things are getting ironed out, but that's been the biggest frustration.\\But it just feels like the company is so driven for results and reaching goals, and we have these lofty aspirations...but are we giving people the respect they deserve? If we're so successful as a company, are we putting that success in the right place? If we want to keep doing business and managing the company the same way companies have been doing for the last hundred years, then fine. But don't tell us to "Lead the Revolution" unless you're really going to change the way a company does business and treats it's employees.

In general I love working for VivintSolar but I do feel that some departments and/or people have a very narrow and closed view of what is best for the company.  I do not enjoy working with such people and would not recommend others to either.

I feel a great amount of anxiety surrounding our being acquired by Sun Edison.  We are nearing the deadline for merger and have not heard anything.  Meanwhile the stock price for Sun Edison has plummeted and there are reports of large scale layoffs on their side already.  This leads one to wonder if the acquisition can or will move forward as planned.  If not, what will this mean for the future of Vivint Solar?  If yes, what does that mean for the Vivint Solar employees entering into an already tumultuous environment.  I understand there are regulations surrounding discussing such things and it is ridiculous for me to have any expectation of information at my level.  At this point I don't know what to pray for.  Is it better for the deal to fall through and we go our separate ways (for now)?  Or is it better for us move forward with the deal and try to change the current downturn as much as we can?
the fact that i have been spending more time out of my day driving and seating  in crazy traffic its not to bad
While working at Vivint Solar its been great coming to work and having a "Work Family"  having people who i can rely on, and I know that they care about me and how I'm doing.

I've loved working for Vivint Solar and its been great to learn about the solar process, and what good we can do in the world.  One of the things that bugs me is that when it comes to promotions, or changing positions it seems like there is a little favoritism in who is selected instead of going off of who is qualified, or who would be a good fit for the position.

I bleed orange, I've worked for Vivint over 2 years and that won't be changing any time soon. Unfortunately I feel this is the first time since I started that we didn't have an identity or vision.. We knew if we wanted to hit this goal we would need to double in size each year which meant a double in opportunity.. Now we don't really know what we are or what the goal is\\Aside from that, all of the constant changes from corporate to the sales process have seemed to make things way more complicated rather than more simplified \\In New York we have a notary step.. In order to submit a permit we need to call corporate and schedule a time for the notary to come by.. This is the most important step to the sales process because it translates to a "sale" and we currently can not schedule a notary unless it's Monday through Friday from 9-5pm\\reps are taught not to close CAD's during that time because they are prime knocking hours, so if we close a cad later in the day after 5 we need to schedule the notary the next day, completely taking the situation out of our control.. That is painful to the process\\I know we will get through it, and I will keep on being positive and helping guys reach their potential but things have been harder lately for sure

Every market is run like its own solar company, we should focus more on replicating the best systems from the best markets rather than creating systems from scratch in every office and learning from mistakes that can be avoided all together
I feel a real sense of pride when I tell people about where I work and what I do. Invariably, people express interest and ask for more info about our process when I discuss work with them.

I like Vivint Solar, I think there are some great aspects of the company. Lack of communication definitely makes it hard for me to know where we are going or what to expect.

I feel like my current leader determines my role responsibilities on how she feels that day. She will always gives multiple tasks and then doesn't set  clear expectations. For me personally I find issues in\\1)The lack of communication from current leader on process changes\2)The lack of defined expectations from current leader\3)The lack of accountability across the board\4)A trail of broken promises to employees from current leader\\Its because of these reasons, I can't recommend any one to work in my current department.\I can't say the same for all departments, just my own.

I think that Vivint Solar s wonderful company and the best place I've ever worked. However I also have some misgivings about some things i had unforeseen but that I and my customers have experience that left me feeling embarrassed and through which I lost some confidence in our company. Some very important customers to me suffered what seemed to me to be an Interminal series of inane in competencies and lack of professionalism, in their eyes. These are all due to dropped balls, lack of communication and lousy procedures in place internally. My OMs assure me that these are anomalies due to extremely fast growth over the summer. I tend to believe them. Perhaps my faith was just too high based upon my years of experience with a small solar contractor with a reputation for high quality finish work  and customer attentiveness. So I've adjusted my expectations of Vivint Solar to be a bit more realistic, given the highly compartmentalizations and insulated divisions of duties. \\Im also concerned that those at the top may be poised to become the sort who feel they are improving the company by squeezing down on perks and benefits while demanding more of us. When at first I was attracted to how gracious and generous compensation seemed to be.,This is only a sense and I don't point to any specific instances yet. Albeit, we seem to be having fewer team lunches and other little team building perks. \\On the whole, however, I know I'm working for and with a great bunch of people who are working hard and collaboratively to be a superior company.  \\And I too, have watched "12 O'Clock High" and know when and how morale and management need to be toned. So it can't be all pudding and tomatoes!
We are given clear and reasonable goals and asked to meet them. We are updated on internal company changes and anticipated new policy and products.

It seems to me that there may be a conveniently exploitive disconnect between treating us as employees but insisting on independent contractor 1099 status. \\I do feel compensation is good, however. \\Still, I'd feel more as though I actually had a job and was a valued part of the company if I were formally employed here. I don't know what direction the company is moving in.\I don't know the level of commitment the company needs due to the unknown answer above.\I was proud when I first started and had the vision that growth and change was encouraged now not so much.\what are we trying to accomplish now that the acquisition has been delayed.\With the unknown of the acquisition everyone comes to work not knowing what the future holds and what to plan for or hope for. When I first started yes, now very unclear and uncertain.\I tried to get a family member to apply for a position here, however, there is a hiring freeze (This is what i was told). So right now I don't encourage anyone because of the freeze and the unknown.

Could we have a plan A presented detailing what will happen when/if the acquisition happens. Then a plan B if the acquisition doesn't happen. Will there be growth with the acquisition or downsizing? What is my value to the company and how much does the company care about my future?

The only concern that has really surfaced is on the level of the technicians, installers and electricians. As more guidelines for safety, quality, speed, production, etc are in stated our jobs are constantly being made more difficult, longer hours, less concern for our opinions and lively hood. We are the ones that physically make the job a reality and have the most physically demanding aspect of this career, yet all the changes taking place seem to put more pressure and strain on us. Feeling though our jobs are always in jeopardy if we happen to have a bad day or on the wrong side of upper management or our family's are in jeopardy because we work excessive hours to help meet production aND sacrifice safety to hit numbers.

My time working for Vivint has been limited. I like the work and appreciate the opportunity that I have with Vivint. My answers are as they are because industries grow and fade all to often. I honestly would like for my opinion to be changed, but that will only come with time.
I believe Vivint does an excellent job of communicating.
