There are a few things that I'd like to express regarding the field and the difference I see from being on the corporate side and the field side.  There are times that things are expressed but have fallen on deaf ears.  Since working for Vivint Solar almost 3 years, I thought working at corporate was hard but seeing what I see out here in the field has brought everything to a whole new perspective.  Let it be known that I have loved working for Vivint Solar since beginning and I hold pride for this company although my faith as waiver a few times.  A few things below are what concerns me at the moment.\\1.  Workers are under appreciated by upper management.  Example:  Why is there only a $10/person budget for Christmas party/dinner?  How does that show any value to those who work the hardest for something they believe in?  \2.  There's been a huge push to lower overtime hours but yet our reps are needing jobs on the board.  One moment we're asked to get everything installed then the next it's hold off cause we can't exceed 40 hours/week.  Sr of Operations says unlimited OT then it changes as it goes down the pipe.  Clear communication is always lost in the mix of things.\3.  Corporate should take those who have experience (not a degree) in the field and utilize their knowledge to manage the office.  \4.  There is a disconnect with the process between corporate and field.  There are some process' that need to be done in house as corporate does not know what goes on in the field (material availability, scheduling conflicts, manpower etc)\\There are more that can be shared but these are just a few.  I hope you can understand where I'm coming from.  I work with others who've come in from different companies i.e Solar City who's minds are blown with our process and communication to smoothly get our customers from sales to PTO.  Like I said before that I pride myself with Vivint Solar but it gets frustrating hearing these from others which has me questioning 'what are we doing and where are we going?'  \\Thanks for letting me have the mic.  Hopefully someone hears me.
I really enjoy working here and look forward for things to come.

Everything that I know and have learned in the company has been great. It has been a great experience and  I love my job. My co-workers are great people and work hard and the perks that come with working here have been awesome. I have never worked for a better company in a better situation.

While I am committed to the company and hope to have new opportunities down the road here, I am not super passionate about my current position. The job was described to me one way, and ended up being a lot different than what I originally thought. With that being the case, I know that this a good company with opportunities to move forward so I will continue to be committed to doing my job well. \\ Since I am fairly new to the company, it's hard to say whether we are moving in the right direction or not. It seems like a lot of things, such as the acquisition, are up in the air and there's no definite answers to questions that employees have. Once that is settled it will be easier to decide whether the company is moving in the right direction. I think the goals we have, with or without the acquisition, are good.\\In addition, I feel that I would be more passionate about the company if we practiced what we preached. For instance, we claim to be an environmentally friendly company yet we don't offer any public transportation assistance (i.e. Frontrunner passes, etc.), we don't recycle, and a ton of food is wasted after lunch, etc. I would take more pride in my work if I felt that the company was truly committed to helping the environment.
I have a great team, we are all committed to doing the best work we can with the resources we have.

I was able to vocalize some of my concerns in other areas. I hope you will have the time to go through it. I believe this company will continue to mature and grow if employees input is considered and taken seriously.

Vivint Solar has taken good care of me and my family, the integrity, generosity, support  is second to none ! Now at the same time , working for a company with outstanding character and helping people \Take control of their utility destiny all while helping our planet ! Welcome to Vivint .

The leadership in our local office is great at keeping me informed of company goals as well as personal goals also making sure I'm working my program as efficiently as possible. Once in a while their is a disconnect between corporate and our local leaders. Also , it seems that their is incompetence  in some of the corporate offices and  can effect moving accounts forward .

Im very thankful  that God has put me in such an incredible company with incredibly great leaders, in the perfect market at the perfect time . Vivint is teaching me how to work within a corporate atmosphere , and is growing me on a personal and business level.  What an honor that I've been asked to chime in on your survey Mr Butterfield , my goal is to one day meet you in person.\All the best , Shane

I have been here for over 2 years and have really loved working here and brought friends here to work but as of right now I feel the culture is changing from what it once was.  I also think that the news with bonuses and raises maybe being put on hold has had an affect on a lot of people's morale.   I still tell everyone where I work but with the acquisition taking its time and the rumblings of it not happening in the media are putting a damper on me telling people 'proudly'.  \I guess the future just seems uncertain right now.  If you would have asked me maybe 4-5 months ago I would have answered Strongly Agree on many of the areas just to give you a gage of where I was.

Love working here I am just concerned about the acquisition and I hope the culture stays.. it has been changing a little lately.  Would also like to get the bonuses and raises that are promised in offer letters.\\Love the direction and the work we are doing and it is still fun to be a part of this great company. \\thanks,
VSLR is home to me. I couldn't ask for a better company to work for.

I've felt a decline in motivation in recent months due to a lack of identity with the company and not being given a clear picture of who we are now, what the new outlook is with the merger and details of what changes are in store.  I am told to continue doing what I'm doing however I notice that what gave me motivation before was having a clear identity and feeling fully informed on what we are and what lies ahead.  For some reason those factors strongly influence my desire to perform, a higher purpose so to speak.  At times I feel in the dark and it is difficult to want to perform for anything when you feel in the dark.  I know we are headed for some good things, just would be nice to know what those are. Maybe a bit more of a rally as we join forces with a new company would be nice so we feel like a team as a whole again.  Also, the other thing that has influenced me to not be encouraging to family and friends about Vivint is the lack of action once an account is installed, getting that customer to the point of an operating system.  I feel there are too many different departments contributing to getting systems permission to operate, and too many individuals waiting on others for separate pieces of requirements- which seem to fall through the cracks and the customer is the one who ends up losing, when I tell them they will start saving money, they don't realize that it is going to take months and months to begin using their new system... It's discouraging and much of it is out of my control.  I feel as though much of my time is spend chasing down information rather than getting out there and getting new sign-ups, which is my best skill- when I get the chance to use it. Thanks for reading
Thank you for considering my previous comments
There's just far too much red tape. Too many hoops to jump through to create an account. I've sold for other solar companies and the process was much easier. CAD's take ages once usage is submitted.
Get some more install crews in Az ASAP. I have been training reps on how to use NLP and its making a big improvement in our volume.

If I was taking this survey 60 days ago, I would have responded "Strongly Agree" to every statement. The challenges we've encountered with Baltimore County have been painful. I've not had a paycheck in over 2 months, and it appears that it will be at least another month before any money starts to flow again. I would have installed at least 150 kW this quarter. I have that much sitting in solids currently but have also lost a bunch of stuff because of the delays. I have so many unhappy customers, I literally am having a hard time sleeping at night. Secondly, and something I feel strongly about, the move to requiring the PPA upfront is, based on an analysis of my personal experiences, a mistake. Or, at least, should be done on a case by case basis. Or Reps with a track-record should be allowed to progress accounts with just the PCCF and usage. When I was getting everything up front, my cancels were higher. With just the PCCF, and then showing my face at the Site Survey, and then coming back with the CAD, I was building lots of credibility and rapport. When it comes time for the PPA etc, it flows and isn't forced. With everything up front, after leaving, people often "feel sold" and had second thoughts about this 20 year agreement, and cancelled. I think we are going in the wrong direction here. Furthermore, several of the solar companies in the area, that we are now competing against, don't require the PPA prior to having a site assessment done. So, we are taking a turn for the worse here competitively. Lastly, I'm very passionate about solar energy. Our family built our own solar hot water back in 1972. This is a cause I feel very strongly about and why I made, what was a pretty major career decision to come to Vivint. In all the various marketing endeavors over the years I've generally earned in the 300-400K a year range. I thought I could do that with Vivint, but am having a hard time seeing that right now. But also as a footnote, I've probably only been able to operate at 50% of my ability due to family health issues. My 94 year old Mom is in her last days, in and out of the hospital more times than I can count the last 6 months, and my wife of 34 years has Leukemia. So, it hasn't been the best of days for me personally which has greatly impacted my productivity with Vivint.

Our DM and DDM for the most part do a great job. Things are generally well communicated. But, problems tend to be ignored or sugar coated.The quality of the work done by some of the install crews was deplorable. The operations piece, admittedly based on my limited experience, is really poorly managed. I've had way to many problems. Also, while some support departments do an amazing job (CAD), many provide the worst service I've seen in my business career. And I've worked with a plethora of different companies in a number of different industries.
I've probably already said too much. Thanks for this opportunity to provide feedback.
Extreme lack of communication between depts. Installers total unproffessionalism multiple violations etc.

Often takes 4 or many more communication attempts to receive answers such as what is this roof/structural/electrical hold for? Why has interconnection not been submitted? Multiple job installs cancelled with no notice or real explanation given. Installs just mysteriously changed with word on street being managers have acces to changing to put their own jobs in instead. No shows on appointments to customers from surveys to installs to service. Multiple violations from town inspectors such as exposed wires etc. When try to do others jobs to get to install like contacting town inspectors since often not done am told to never do someone elses job. But when job goes sideways told I am 100% responsible for my accts. Surveyers constanly not completing or even submitting info. Many many more problems endemic to operations. New programs email services introduced with complete ridiculous problems. Always same excuse "We are the biggest, best don't worry just get more accounts." Meanwhile customers either threating lawsuits or "I wouldn't recommend your company to my worst enemy!" Hard to press forward with this ongoing daily.
I don't think the reps are valued enough. Corporate is a huge headache to deal with and they are always backed up delaying installs or causing loss of installs through poor response/decisions.

I think reps should see they are appreciated more. I also think for all the work and hours that go in, reps should be paid more per KW. In my opinion, corporate needs a big restructuring. It doesn't seem like they are as focused on getting accounts progessed to install when every minute counts for reps. It would also be really helpful if we could do more roof types. I have so many accounts that would go in if we could only do a wider variety of roofs.

The company feels very "sales centric." Sales seems to get what they want, even when it is not in the best interested of the business. From covering areas too large to operate efficiently in, despite operations protests, to forcing installs on roofs that will likely leak there are a lot of things that get pushed through that ultimately hurt the company. There also seems to be a double standard of accountability. Sales persons who commit forgery, fraud and outright lie to customers somehow keep their jobs ("get internet until you have PTO, then cancel it). We seem to spend much more on sales incentives, videos, training, social media videos etc. I would love nothing more than to see us truly unified across the company, but until the special treatment ends, it won't happen. This general feeling of team sales and ops, instead of team VSLR, the attitude of whats best for me (closing a sale) vs whats best for the company (installing a profitable account), is the biggest reason I answered as I did above.

This impending merger has made things very hard for everyone "in the trenches."  Everyone seems to be in the dark and worried. There has been almost no clear communication as to what is going on.We learn more from news articles than our own leadership. Common questions are: What happens if the merger goes through? What happens if it fails? Do we have enough cash on hand if it does fail?
I sincerely appreciate the opportunity to offer feed back. Please be more transparent & keep the field informed on where the business is headed. Lack of information is never a good thing.

My direct supervisors are amazing.  Some of the best I have had in any company ever.  Darrell and Brady both are fantastic and are some of the best leadership role models I have seen.  I do feel that there is a disconnect between corporate employees, sales staff, and technicians that disrupts the flow of the company as all three need to be working in concert to have anything accomplished.

It can be incredibly frustrating to even track down who I need to speak to about a specific issue.  Recently we started getting emails about holds which may solve much of this.  But I have repeatedly in the short time I have worked for the company found issues where I had to talk to multiple people to even find out who I needed to email to resolve a hold or some other random issue with an account.  That being said I am more than fairly compensated for my work, but the efficiency of this company is probably less than half of what it could be.  Considering it is a 5 year old project that is not terribly bad, but there is room to grow in communication and efficiency in my opinion.
I believe more frequent 'incentives' are the best way to hit the lofty goals/numbers rolled out by corporate especially with the 20% pay cut many of us took with the switch to hourly.
I am just more curious about this sun Edison buyout and if it truly going to help the company or hurt it.
what is up with the rsu's for foreman.  there should be some extra category in pay stub to actually show how much we are accumulating.
I have great leadership on the SS side and I enjoy the challenge of managing my surveyors.

We hear a lot of rumors about the merger going through or not going through.  It will be nice when that is done (one way or the other).  I am excited about the possibilities that the merger would bring.\\I would like to have the ability to purchase company stock within my 401k at NAV.  \\I heard about the lay-offs of installers.  It seems like corporate is trying to keep that a secret.  I think that it would be better to be in front of it instead of it getting out and Vivint looks like they were trying to hide things. (just my opinion).\\I enjoy working for Vivint Solar.  I think that the name change to GO Solar is brilliant!\\I am concerned about my surveyors at the moment.  They have low survey volume due to low sales.  Now with the new rules on surveying with a signed PPA, volume will no doubt take another hit.  We will probably be overstaffed.  \\I know a lot about the importance of cost/watt, but I don't think that the average employee knows much at all.  It is of the utmost importance!  (I talk to my 3 year old like she is a mature little person, not a baby... She doesn't act like a baby any longer).  I think that we need to treat the employees like adults and team members and talk to them on an adult level about why cutting costs is so important.  The ones who take it seriously and strive to cut costs after knowing the importance are ultimately the ones that we want on our team. (just my opinion)\\I thoroughly enjoy working for Vivint Solar!  I appreciate your leadership and I am confident that we are innovative and resilient enough to become the largest and most influential solar company in the nation!  (with or without SunEdison)

I feel that my office is very political. The people who are recognized are the friends of the managers. I also find it funny whenever there are office contests, the managers include themselves so I see that it does NOT motivate most of the sales team because they feel cannot win.

Leadership at the company is very immature. This leads to bad decisions in regard to legal compliance, financial decisions, training, etc.\\We raised millions of dollars in our IPO,  we were told that would cover our G&A activities until 2018, yet we burned through that money  with incentives, bad sales programs, out of control overtime, etc. We talk about being good and doing good, but what are we doing? We don't have charity programs or service activities. I see lots of activities that seem to waste resources and money with no real impact to installation, sales, or employee morale. We were promised a 401k match in 2015 and that hasn't happened. \\I believe in the business model and what we sell as a product, but we seem to have no direction internally to sell the company to the employees and involve all employees in the progress toward goals.\\My annual bonus is tied to the performance and spending of other departments; departments whose own bonuses are not dependent on meeting the same metrics. Not all departments are eligible for the POM program. \\When applying for a promotion and the process was 99% complete, including approval of my manager and managers manager, company policy was changed to preclude me from getting said promotion.\\The acquisition has been a giant black hole for the organization from lack of communication with what is happening, employees leaving due to lack of communication, hiring/promotion freeze, etc. \\Overall, I think we can go places and do good things, but that requires more than a few pictures around the office and saying the words. We need some real morale boosting

I am grateful to work for a company that has great intentions. Many companies care for money alone and will do anything to obtain it without thinking twice about the harm they may be causing along the way. This is not the case for Vivint Solar, a company that is dedicated to Earth's health and to saving the customer money on their power bill. Although the rapid growth is often chaotic, I am optimistic about the opportunities to advance that will naturally arise.

I took the position that I am currently in because I was excited to be a part of the organization as it was described to me at the time. I also liked the fresh aspect of what Vivint Solar is trying to accomplish by being a part of the green industry. \\However, my passion in my current role has been compromised by a combination of poor leadership, and the pending deal with Sun Edison. In reference to poor leadership, I would like to specifically call out Tessa White, the current VP of HR. It is obvious to everyone who works with her (directly and indirectly) that she is not qualified for the role she is in, nor is she an effective manager of people and processes. Many of the decisions and mistakes she has made has negatively affected the organization and is the main reason for abrupt the exit of employees in her department.\\As for the Sun Edison merger, it appears ​this was a bad decision from the beginning. It is clear that it is not going to be beneficial for the organization, or its employees.

One of the most frustrating aspects of working for Vivint Solar is that we do not have the resources to fully do our jobs. The continual unfocused change to business processes makes it difficult to have consistent, accurate results. In addition, the organization structuring of departments is constantly changing, and many employee's direct supervisors also change, which makes it hard to know and understand expectations. \\Also, the work environment makes it hard for us to perform effectively our jobs. In some cases, like call centers, the table-style work desks are appropriate. However, for other departments, they are not. We do not have the privacy needed to manage prop​erly sensitive data.
Please seriously consider hearing my comments, as well as other employees. It is not my intention to bash the organization, I really do care about the overall mission.

As an independent sales manager in charge of my own expenses, benefits, etc. I don't feel as linked to the company as if I were an actual employee of the company with access to benefits, stock options, etc.
Resources are difficult to find and many times I feel like I'm running in circles to get things done.

This isn't just a company, it feels more like a family of brothers that I work with and everyone is always there to lend a helping hand. Everyone looks out for the best interest in each other and this isn't just a job to me, it's a career and lifestyle. I love what I do and every day after I clock out after working in the freezing cold, heat waves, or the pouring rain I remember the days that I had nothing and Vivint solar gave me this opportunity to create a future, with me having just a GED. I am beyond grateful for this chance at life I was given by this company. Thank you for everything you and this company does to make this world a greater place.
love the culture, people and mission of vslr.

We need more bodies in fleet performance (not my dept but i work with them). part of a sales rep's pitch is that we monitor the system and they only pay if it's working. unfortunately we don't have the bandwidth to monitor systems and i hear from countless customers and reps who voice their concern over their underperforming system. just today a rep brought up an account that was "overproducing" because it was picking up 37 inverters from a neighbor. We've been overcharging this customer for months even though the customer has been complaining. I do know post merger we can address this but it hurts my heart that we can't help monitor all systems.

If our task were likened to finding and chopping down trees (as sales), it has felt like we have been given a very dull ax to do the task (if the ax were operations running smoothly).  I feel like I could have chopped down twice as many trees in my 18 mos. with the company if the ax had been sharpened more - with the same or less effort. We've been promised help and improvement - hopefully this time it comes so we can more effectively complete our task, help our customers, and continue to change the world.

One thing that I've felt would be valuable in my time with the company, is a way to get ideas/suggestions from the front lines to places/people where they can be heard and possibly implemented in order to benefit us as a whole. I believe many great ideas can surface from the front lines - we are dealing directly with customers and roadblocks in distributing our product. However, it feels when these ideas/suggestions come up they have no where to go and be heard (even as a DM). \\For example - we have a newer rep in our office who is retired, and spent 30+ years as a lean process/manufacturing engineer for his career. His brain is full of ways that could help our operations be more lean and efficient; as he is seeing what is happening first hand. He has come to me with suggestions, many of which I think are great - I have tried to get them somewhere to help but they don't seem close to getting where they would need to go for proper implementation. \\It's understandable that every suggestion won't work/benefit the company, but it could prove very useful to implement a better way for suggestions to be heard, and maybe some new ideas will arise that can help transform our company into a more efficient, lean, and effective machine.  \\Thank you for personally reaching out for our input- I believe in our mission as a company and in you as our leader!

I've been working for this company for 2 years and Ive seen how much ive grown and the people around me. I love the environment and culture that we display at VSLR. Also, VSLR is constantly changing and growing which is a great sign of growth
I don't know where the company stands inregards to projections and goals and how we directly impact them
I love VSLR. Thank you for the opportunity that it presents to me and my fellow co-workers:)

I have seen older employees and brand new hires that I'm concerned about. To my eyes, if your not pulling your own weight or even not trying to, Why keep them here? They are just wasting company's time and money. There are plenty of way better people who are dedicate and will do way better work.

I like working at my Boston north office. I've seen alot of changes for the good at my office since I started in may 2013, and feel positive we getting better. My vision for the future, I would like to see more dedicated employees, who understand the company's vision s and value s. Who works hard and cares about what we are doing for our customers and the world. Not just thinking that, it's just a job or a paycheck. I don't like to see employees complained about a job, roof tilts, getting wet, too windy, too many arrays, too hot etc., I wish I could tell them, if you don't this job, why are you still here? I know first hand that this line of work is not for everyone. It would be a better place to work, if everyone cares about their job and the company. I am proud to be working as a Vivint employee and going green.

promotions are based on who you are friends with not what you know or your skills. As a specific example, myself and others I know have been here longer than any of our supervisors or department managers, have more experience with the company, and industry than them, and yet we are passed over for promotion again, and again in favor of those who are friends with each other. Watching the current CAD supervisors (as a team lead) most of them are more interested in flirting with each other and having their leads do both the lead and the supervisor jobs than they are in actually working.

Computers have finally gotten usable after 3 years, but they could be better when it comes to the design department. My current supervisor is better than those i've had in the past and actually does his job and relays info to us as it relates to our team. However I know nothing about what is happening in the company as a whole. I haven't heard about sun edison since summer, I haven't heard about the new building since the ground breaking, I don't know if we plan on opening new offices or what type of growth we expect.

As a designer I feel like we are under valued. According to the utah department of workforce services the average starting pay for a CAD drafter is $16 in the state, vs the $10 here, it may have recently gone up so the $10 may no longer be accurate. According to Onetonline.org the average utah pay for drafters is $36,050 annually, compared to the national average of $49,990 annually, both of which are substantially higher than our company. Estimating an average pay of $12 for the designers here would be $24,960 annually. Onetonline.org doesn't have a PV system designer job salary info as that is generally the responsibility of the Solar Energy System Engineer whose duties are greater than ours and so are paid more, as such I compared us to a general drafter salary.
We need to do a better job taking care of customers. The PTO process takes too long. The baton gets passed through too many people. I wish we had in house CSM and processing in the local office.
I feel the savings calculator may be giving  me incorrect information

I believe the customer comes first.no short cuts. We still Ned to measure all the roof because it seems that other company's don't they do an Ariel and that's what makes us better going the extra mile.

This company is great I love what I do and what the company provides to our customers. But at times it does seem like my team (Click Support and Real Time scheduling) gets overlooked. We do a lot of great work with no real reward or praise. It does make it seem like our little department is a whole separate team and not involved with the company.
This goes to the same issues I mentioned before, we sometimes don't have the resources that the CSM's have.  Such as incentives, direct feedback from upper management.

There is a big emphasis on installing customers but from that point on everything lags. I'm getting many customers who's PTO process is ridiculously slow leading to high customer dissatisfaction and a lack of referrals which is making my job much harder and lowering my morale on the doors. It's also where most of the negative reviews we battle have their origins. I believe in this product. It is an amazing necessary change in the way we power our world and I actually started with Vivint because I got installed to lower my personal carbon foot print and I thought it would be amazing to help others do the same while saving them money at the same time. I'm hopeful to get out there with full confidence again and to see improvement in these areas, when that happens: sky's the limit for us, customer & employee satisfaction will be through the roof and the business will grow so much faster because referrals, reviews & word of mouth should be launching us forward not holding us back

18 Months of Experience in the company.  I definitely feel it is headed in the right direction.  I have also seen the growing pains.  But I see improvements often.  I enjoy working here.  I think being split up has hurt the 'culture' and hope the new central building will bring that back by being less divided.
I think there could be improvements to Post hire training.  I know things are changing all the time so that makes it difficult.  And I have seen communication from management on down improving.

I think things are going well.  I haven't heard of our Quarterly meeting, which I've become accustomed to.  Also haven't heard much about the merger lately.  But this also leads to rumors and whispers.  And while I haven't heard anything bad, It does leave questions.  \But I like the direction we are headed, and I recommend working here to people I meet.

In past six months, with all of the changes that have transpired, the feel of the company has changed a lot. There is a general feeling that we, the people in the field who do the labor upon which this company was built, are just numbers, a commodity to be manipulated and sold.
Its very hard to get things done. Most customers are not happy. the sales reps line of communication is cut to zero.

at the end of the day all those latedah emails sent dont mean anything to me. I want to know whats going on with my accounts and the ability to communicate directly with the person whos responsible for the task. There is no accountability in our infrastructure . The people who have access succeed. The pipe line sucks.

The install crew is pushed or expected to finish a in one day.  I understand why but there are some jobs that cannot be done in one day but we stay until the job is finished which leaves us (install and electrical crew) getting home late and missing out on home and family time.

I love working for Vivint Solar and enjoy coming to work every day. The only question that's hard is whether we are moving in the right direction. There is a lot of uncertainty about our future, so I don't even know in what direction we are moving. I have a lot of reluctance about becoming part of SunEdison. I haven't heard great things about them, and I'm afraid it will change our culture for the worse.

I regularly receive information about what's going on, but it seems to change constantly. I don't put a lot of weight when I hear news, because I assume that within a week, our direction or status will be different than expected. \\As an employee in the corporate office, I would love to hear more about our Operations goals and how we are doing achieving those goals. I know we have install goals, but I don't know what they are or how we are doing with them.

I have great people on my team that are going far above and beyond right now, especially because we can't backfill open positions. I would really like to be able to reward them with spot bonuses or promotions, but I understand that we have a "freeze" on financial incentives right now. It is hard to keep people motivated when they see a lot of people around them leaving. Can we put some additional retention/incentive dollars aside to reward people?

I feel like it's a constant struggle with submitting online paperwork. I feel like corporate should be making our jobs easier instead of constantly rejecting documents. As a sales rep, we are on the front lines and dealing with so much already. I feel like we should be taken care of and compensated for the work we're doing.

I am extremely passionate about my job, my work, and what we are trying to accomplish as a company. I do, however, feel that throughout the year(s) we have become distracted with the direction we are moving and have moved back in forth in short sprints in different directions. I am excited to see us get back on track with a clear path and goals to work towards. I am excited to see us find or re-establish the identity of our company.
I feel that a lot of the sales reps are dishonest and I have to work with them and do their illegal work.  Don't like doing that.
My supervisors are great and we know what to do, but we don't know when or how anything is happening. Ever.

I feel strongly about the company and the mission we are on, however I feel like there is a significant disconnect with the field, and the constant effort to "centralize" everything creates a very difficult situation for us as salespeople as well as a very disconnected experience for the customer. I have been with Vivint for a long time and my hesitation to encourage people to work for us or offer our service to those I know comes from the lack of follow through and accountability others are held to. I have years of experience in the trades as an electrician and I cannot speak for other offices but for the market where I work, it is clear that the local operations manager is not in that position due to merit, qualification or hard work. He had been less than helpful in any regard to my accounts and I have had to work directly with the sales manager to get things taken care of for my customers. Someone in that position should be there more that just to collect a check. I don't know if the situation locally is a reflection of the company as a whole, but the lack of interest in correcting issues as they come up makes it difficult not to think that there is a genuine disinterest in the success of the individual sales people or the customers we work with.
Thank you for the opportunity to be a part of something meaningful. I hope we can make the small changes needed to right to ship and get us back on top.

I've worked for this company for a long time - longer than I've ever worked anywhere - and I care quite a bit about how things are done and the people I work with.  I've seen how we've grown from a two-room enterprise in the Dynex building to overflowing out of many buildings in multiple cities.  I feel like I have put a lot of my life into this job.  \\That being said, I feel like we're drifting away from that "we're all in this together" familial air we used to have.  I used to feel like my voice made a difference and that I was empowered to make change in my team and my department, that I was part of something, but I don't get that anymore.  It seems that numbers rule my life now and that it's all I can do to not be written up for not getting my team to work harder.  I feel so much more scrutinized for my small mistakes, than I do lauded for my achievements.  There's so much pressure to be perfect and to not let anything slack that I'm starting to feel anxiety about just coming to work.  \\Granted, I know some of these things are just natural symptoms of growing and becoming a corporate powerhouse, but still - I don't feel like Vivint Solar is on my side anymore. That makes me really sad.

I think that what we are doing is valuable and I am surrounded by incredible coworkers. At the same time, we have a lot of archaic processes and our ability to execute hasn't kept up with growth. I'm concerned about that in context of increasing competition and the possible upcoming cut to solar ITC.

I know we continue to invest in data and people, but sometimes it is difficult, with competing budgets, to have the best of both. I understand my role and how I'm measured, but I'm unsure how other parts of the business view their role in context of our overall success.

I am very satisfied with this company, I am so thankful that I was Hired on. Being a Husband and a Father of six children, It is great to work for a successful company who really does care about their employees.

I am appreciative and impressed of the support I've received from my superiors. If there is ever an opportunity to give Jordan Huber and Jason Andersen a role with more responsibility and a greater impact on the company, give it to them. You won't find a more dedicated and effective leader than those two. Vivint Solar has been a blessing to me as I grow to become a more impactful individual. Thank you for this opportunity.
I would like to have more communication & wish that my office and the company would get more organize in general.

Company could use better methods of communication.  We're working in so many different systems and it would be nice if we had an intranet page where all employees could go to look at company policies, receive updates, and access forms and information.

Company lacks incentives and recognition for corporate employees, focusing all rewards and incentives on Sales and Installations employees.  Many departments are  short-staffed considering the company's growth.

I enjoy my job.  My supervisor is flexible and understanding of work-life balance.  Free lunch is great.  It would improve the company greatly if there were a better way to communicate policies and procedures across the company.  I also feel that the company is severely lacking in sufficient manager training for its supervisors.  Much of our workforce is young and inexperienced, including supervisors and managers.  We should give them the information  they need (HR, safety, compliance, basic leadership skills, communication skills, etc.) to lead effectively and confidently.  We're currently throwing them out there as sheep and expecting them to lead wolf packs.  Invest in your supervisors and it will unify and inspire your workforce.
Because its the truth. I love doing what I do and. I feel appreciated at work by other coworkers. And the atmosphere here is outstanding, everyone is happy glad to be here.

Vivint is the company that is known for taking care of their employees, and that they have do exactly. I'm very happy to work for a company that is not in it just for themselves but for every person in the company.

I have been at BOSTON NORTH for almost be month and I absolutely love my job. I have the best crew,  we get along and work very well together. I wake up excited at 330am to come to work every day.  I feel vivint solar is moving a a fast strong growth pace, all though we have competition no one can beat us!

I have always wanted to be part of Vivint Solar years ago, I was nervous to make the leap as an electrician with a solid job . But after 4 months of being here I am beyond pumped that I have made this choice. I'm excited to come to work everyday. Great employees to work with and great atmosphere makes for an unbeatable team at Boston North. Woburn.Thank you for giving me this opportunity! !

There are no words to describe how amazing this opportunity is for my family and I.  Everyday I am exited and blessed to be able to call myself a member of the Vivint Solar family!  Thank you so much for all you do for us and I look forward to succeeding and growing with the company!!!

Since I started at Vivint over the past few years the company as more than tripled. This tells me that people are make good decisions on all levels from the techs right up to the top managers in corp.

I greatly enjoy working for this company. I feel valued and respected, which is a far cry more than I can say for some of the other jobs I've had in my professional career. I like feeling like I'm making a difference, and I like that I can keep up with the work here. Vivint Solar challenges me, and I notice my growth each day. I can definitely attribute the development of most of my professional skills and talents to the time and work I've put into this company.

One thing this company suffers from is a lack of communication. I know what's expected of me partially because that's what I already expect of myself. However, I feel like I don't get a lot of information about where we are both on the level of individual departments as well as a company. Communication is key to success, and I feel like if we're not communicating, we're not growing, we're not understanding, and we're not succeeding.

As a Customer Success Manager, I feel like I don't know what's going on with our company. I know we're merging with Sun Edison, but when? I know we're struggling in other departments, but what do they need to be successful, and how can I help? Why isn't this being communicated to other departments? I know we're making changes to the structures and processes we work in, but where's the training? Where's the communication? What do I need to pay attention to, and what is obsolete now? I know as a CSM, I have more power and responsibility, but what exactly am I expected to do? I feel like my job description is vague and the lines of responsibility are blurred, if not missing altogether. As a result, people expect me to do things I didn't think fell under my umbrella, which leads to confusion, delays, and escalations. What resources can you provide to help  me be more successful?\\I don't feel heard, but more importantly, I don't feel included in the news and updates about what's going on. Knowing is half the battle, and if I don't know what's going on, I can't fight the good fight very well. I'm only doing a job half as well, and I need more information.
I just wanted to mention how thankful I am to be a part of Vivint Solar and this opportunity.

It is a beautiful thing to work for a company that allows me to be completely transparent to all homeowners, and not have to lie once. Plus I am helping the environment and the Nation, all while saving homeowners money.
We have meetings all the time and we receive emails.
I have worked with chance Allred for my entire adult life for the most part. I'm very confident in the leadership due to their demonstrated performance over time.
I think communication is very high. The truth is I'm a recruiter so I'm not as dependent as a sales manager would be.

Consistency. I spend a lot of time with sales reps, DMs, divisionals, and directors. The big cloud that sometimes seems to loom in uncertainty. Whether it's Apollo, pay, or just a process it seems like there is a lack of consistency at times and I think it causes negativity.

Everyday I am super grateful for the oppurtunity to come to work for such a solid company that I am proud to represent. Being part of Vivint Solar is like being part of a second family, with amazing energy. I am especially grateful for the dynamic being that I am one of the only females\ Reps in the office/ region, and there is no where else I feel more comfortable than with my team. I am proud to be a part of a company's who's goals are to save families money and save our environment, while working with integrity. Truly grateful to be a part of the team!
Sometimes in my opinion, the ball may get dropped along the process at any point, making the steps in the process leading to installation much more time and attention consuming for the sales rep.

The changes I've seen the past year are drastic and for the positive to the changes that were made the first two years I've worked with the company.  Completely bought in and excited to see where we'll be one year from now.
Mic check.  Looking forward to getting past what ever may happen with this acquisition.  I like the way we're heading and think the addition of leaders are already making a huge impact.

Since the merger I feel we have had no direction from management. There has been no updates to the process and when you start to see people in director level and above positions leave and question items it makes you nervous as an employee. I feel like the executive staff is not syncing with each other and working for Paul's department makes you feel like he runs you in one direction and then another with never much thought behind the decision.

Biggest concern is the time it takes to see updates on IT development and access to saleforce, mercury for new employees.\\Changing emails has been a huge hit to the productivity of our organization.  I receive constant complaints about how difficult it is to use the new google email especially with group emails.
Some processes could be more efficient.
I am not a fan of Apollo. I would give it an average rating when it is performing at its best.

Firstly, I should state that I am meeting, or exceeding, my permitting goals each week. I quit a tenure-track position at a university to become a Vivint Solar sales rep in Las Vegas, NV. We all know how that ended up. I am now in Albuquerque, NM dealing with lengthy sale to install times because this market clearly wasn't ready either. While my experience may be an anomaly, I nonetheless feel like joining Vivint Solar has been a poor career move on my part as I  haven't seen a 'real' paycheck since I resigned from the university.
Working for vivint has been a wonderful experience, it's definitely had its ups and downs but over all a very pleasurable work environment.
I'm am excited to see what new opportunities come along with all the new changes. I'm am single and willing to relocate if necessary.

Just a special thanks to vivint. It feels very good to be part of a company who really is trying to help people save money through renewable energy. \ As a solar installer I can say that we are literally saving the world one panel at a time.

I love my job. I love working for this company. I only hope that what I do noticed, and that the company knows how I feel about working for them. I would like to only grow with this company, but one day retire from here as well. I will not stop climbing the latter, and taking the steps necessary to become an asset to Vivint/Go Solar. Hard work I am no stranger to, but there is so much in this field that is new and intriguing to me. I look forward to learning as much as I can so I can continue to be challenged and educated as I grow with the company.
I've worked many jobs, and am happy to have finally found a career. I am happy to be apart of the Vivint family and am looking forward to being a success at every aspect of my job.

This company has a great deal of potential. Many who work here are highly structured and organized, however the company itself is not. There is no uniform process for people to follow, yet. I can see it coming together though if handled correctly.

Things change often, such as what roof types we can install on. Trying to solve problems such as holds on an account can be incredibly frustrating. That's just an example. To much contention and blame seems to occur.

This company seems great on the surface, but there is a lot of contention that comes from the egos of the different departments. There is a lot of feel good talk and praise for those who are doing well. Problems and concerns go unanswered and ignored for the most part. Many in management positions have not idea or business being managers. They need a little more training themselves at times. Overall though, it's a great company full of opportunity and promise. As long as a uniform process gets put in place, it will go far and succeed. Without that, I think we will face serious problems and setbacks. Customer service must be more important than egos.

I've never worked for a company with such rich culture like Vivint Solar. Everyday gets better and we offer the greatest product out there, something that is saves the world from harmful emissions and saves them money!

I'm excited to be part of the energy revolution that is taking place and enjoy the hard work and challenges we take on.  Although here would be concerns I have... I like this forum because many times one feels they can't say what their thinking in fear to be seen as negative or not on board. I'm on board and very loyal to the company.\ If I was to ask executives why should a customer go with Vivint I would be curious to hear the answer. In fact that would be my challenge before your next Monday call, ask that question and see if the answer is true or not or based on the reviews given by customers is what they said true. Better panels? Supreme service? Better price? Better program? Better sales reps? Easy process to go from sale to install.. Because I think we're getting best on all fronts.\- our pto times are crazy slow, 6 months plus to get a customer turned on and we didn't do anything for that customer.  No call saying hey will give a month free etc.  we waited till they called in or the sales rep paid out of pocket to calm them down.  Processing paperwork takes multiple attempts on many occasions.  We've had customers who have had damage to their homes meaning a leak and ceiling covered in water Stain and take over 6 months to get it fixed.  Those small battles we're losing.  In 4 years we still don't have a clean system down that doesn't lose customers along the way.  our managers are not doing a good job training reps. They hire, train, manage others accounts and manage their own.  Priority being on their own,  they can't slow down to fix problems because slowing down would be seen as not producing and not working not creating new accounts. I know some as dm  who not one time went and helped another close a cad that wasn't their own.  They are spread to thin and in return do a mediocre job at all.  We mock solar city because they don't want their Dms sole focus to be personal accounts and then do programs such as mentor program that shines a light on how many accounts are stuck because they don't know how to move them.  But the amount of work it takes to micro manage an account from sale to pto which all falls on the rep takes a lot of time.  we should be focused on how can we get our solar reviews from a 1 star to a 5 star and how can we get a rep to know what he's doing.  We have some of the most talented people working for us but there is a large disconnect from Corp to the field in what is seen on a spreadsheet to be happening and the actual process it takes to get a customer through our process.  I've seen some from Corp go out for a day and follow a rep.  But that rep was either a leader or wasn't going to talk about how hard it is to get through the process.  I know we are working on solutions for everything I've listed.  I do feel like the people working on them haven't been in the field and don't realize the pressure of going back to a customers home after we haven't provided them a good service, and while we're focusing on getting the next install and leaving the other behind we don't realize when providing a bad service were in turn making it harder and harder to get new sales.  We make policy like payments and contracts signed thinking that will make better accounts, while I agree that helps, what would really help is after someone just signed a 20 year ppa after only knowing someone for 30 min and googled Vivint solar it was good news they found not bad.    All in all I'm excited and know this is the right place to be, I live everyday for the challenge, but there is some large holes to be filled. I love the people I work with and am excited to win, but I believe our arrogance is hurting us and not allowing us to see the small things that matter.  I am very grateful for you and also know there are many at Corp who are working endless hours to help us and I really appreciate that.  Truthfully I'm grateful to have a job with Vivint solar.

System Install Accuracy at install and timely responses to rejections. CSM's at local office level providing "local customer service", timely responses to complaints, scheduling etc. in real time. Customer Satisfaction emphasis from everyone...sampling of customers experience by poll or survey from initial contact through PTO. We will not get referrals from dissatisfied customers.

I was asked by my Manager Julius Gillmore if I knew any good electrician 's. He told me there is a  $700 referral payout. I referred Ricardo Castaneda licensed electrician. But was never paid for my referral. I was really counting on that $700...so not too happy about being misled on what was promised to me
Just would like to see more opportunities for growth within the company.....

We need to figure out how to get the townships to move faster on approving permits & the PSEG's of the World to move faster on interconnection and PTO Process... We are creating get customers , than\pissing them off due to how long it takes to get permitted and the long long time to PTO...\We are losing the referral part of the business by the long waits for the solar process in Long Island and I'm sure in other parts of the NE...

Make the Insurance part of the New PPA More transparent and easy to understand for the Avg. home\Owner .. Their home is their biggest investment.. They want to know clearly how our coverage and protection really works and applies to their home... THIS IS A BIG ONE !!!!
The merger is causing lots of uncertainty. Let's get on with it already.
IT support for sales force is poor. Way to many issues with Apollo, PDA, Mercury, etc. need more resources to support and innovate so the sales team can be confident in their tools
Thank you for all that you do.
Training states one thing but management says another. No more drive to do bigger jobs, no panel pay. We spend more time redoing CADs then actually doing the job.

Though I've only been at the company for less than a year and my perspective is limited, I feel as though the company will hastily make decisions without adequately performing analysis or having sufficient conversations as to if it is the best course of action. I understand that some things are outside of our control and it is difficult to foresee that such things will delay or stop our growth (i.e. net metering laws, permit approvals, etc.); however, we are quickly moving in to new areas with the intent to earn more money and business but end up spending more than we receive (i.e. Las Vegas or South Carolina). Although I'm excited that we are growing, I also feel that we should first strengthen those areas where we are currently present and have already established a reputation. I think the same thing can be said about our constantly changing compensation plans and new sales channels. I feel that we make decisions without first figuring out how it's all going to work. I feel that we, as the saying goes, will "put the cart before the horse." This, in turn, causes additional manual work for those supporting groups. I feel that some stress could be reduced if decisions were made with more analysis of the opportunities and threats as well as defining the processes. Again, all this is said through my perspective and without the whole picture. This is just my findings based on my work load and perspective.

I enjoy the monthly emails that we receive from you informing us and encouraging us. They are both informational and inspirational. I feel that some additional training and defining of roles can be done on the sales end (i.e. DMs and DDMs) because I don't feel that the chain of command is followed very often when dealing with problems. Often, have I found, that problems will be escalated to the VP's without first being worked through with direct supervisors. I understand that it could be the culture of the sales environment. It would be beneficial if the company offered classes (i.e. Excel Analytic's, VBA, Excel Statistics, etc.) that would help us be more proficient at our jobs. I enjoy learning new skills and would take advantage of such classes. I understand that I may be in the minority though.

I appreciate you offering a way for us to provide feedback. I sincerely hope that you understand that I am not trying to be critical. I think that the company does a lot of things well. I have also began to recognize some of our weaknesses. I am committed to turning our weaknesses into strengths but we all need to recognize them. I feel that to many decisions are driven off of sales department. Again, my perspective is limited. Thank you and have a great day!

The business often asks for things as a 'wish list' they want.  Sometimes without a clear understanding of requirements or features.  Every department thinks their needs are top priority.  It is impossible to accommodate everyone and a challenge to figure out what will give the most ROI.  I end up doing things multiple times because my customers didn't clearly define requirements up front. The push to meet deadlines seems paramount at times, yet the products are not used for weeks, or months afterwards, leading to frustration and disappointment.

I have only worked here for about 8 months and have enjoyed being here a great deal. The work is challenging and satisfying. I was disappointed to learn that there is no incentive for employees to install solar at their homes.  It would be nice if I could purchase a system at a discounted rate as an employee.\Overall I am very happy working here and hope Vivint.solar feels the same way about me.
I love my career in Solar. It's changed my families lives and we are grateful for this opportunity .

It just feels lately like the company is moving away from really being "for the workers", and that was something Vivint always expressed-Family. Alot has been taken away from us recently and were trying to have hope things will improve. Thanks
It's a privilege to work for Vivint Solar. I like the simple concept, it's what sells.

I used to feel like part of the company. I've put tons of hours and blood sweat and tears into this office. I worked 70+ hours on a regular basis; not for the money or hours, but to accomplish what has been done in the department I am in charge of. Not so much anymore.

The company has dropped the ball with the rollout of the CSM. It is not working in the current structure and the company has been slow to adjust their mistake. Technology is way behind the eight ball and productivity would go up tremendously if the systems were adjusted.costs would be reduced also. Too much human intervention.
I love my job,I see my results every day, I am appreciated for my expertice and I am not micro managed and it is an exciting time to work for Vivint. Thanks, Greg.
I have only been here for 6 months and I am surprised every day of how much I enjoy the people I work with. The ELT is very dedicated to the success of the company.
